(d)  The owner will be required to pay all expenses involved and a fee of $20.00 per day per animal for each day the animal was housed at the animal shelter. The total amount of the daily housing fee is to be retained by the animal shelter. 
(e)  In the event the vicious animal investigation leads the dog control officer to believe the allegation is unfounded, the dog control officer will advise the complainant of his findings and submit the results of the investigation to his supervisor. 
(f)  A copy of all investigations made pursuant to this section will be kept on file in the police department. 
(g)  There is an annual $25.00 registration of animals deemed vicious by municipal court or penalty of $150.00 for nonregistration within two weeks required to be paid. 
(Ord. No. 2010-019, § 4-42, 8-17-2010)  
Sec. 10-83. - Enclosure specifications for vicious animals. 
Whenever a vicious animal is permitted to stay or remain in the city, the following requirements and any other requirements deemed necessary and appropriate for public safety by the supervisor shall be adhered to by the owner of said vicious animal: 
(1)  Owners shall provide an exterior perimeter fence suitable to contain an average animal of the same type. The perimeter fence shall be constructed of chainlink or wooden privacy type and shall be at least four feet in height. 
(2)  Owners shall provide an additional fence or pen of adequate size inside the perimeter fence to humanely confine the vicious animal. 
a.  This additional fence or pen may not share common fencing with the perimeter fence; 
b.  This additional fence or pen must have secure sides and a secure top attached at all sides; 
c.  All four sides of this additional fence or pen must be sunk at least two feet into the ground or the fence or pen must be built over a concrete pad to prevent the animal from digging out; 
d.  This additional fence or pen must have an inward opening gate and shall be kept locked at all times by padlock or key lock except when tending to the care of the animal; 
e.  The sides of this additional fence or pen shall be from ground to top at least twice the height of the animal, the height of the animal being measured from its shoulders; 
f.  This additional fence or pen must not be positioned so that neighbors or passersby have access to the animal. It must be no less than 20 feet from any neighboring home; and 
g.  Signs shall be posted on each side of this additional fence or pen stating that a vicious animal is enclosed and shall specify the type of animal enclosed, i.e., a vicious dog. 
The fence/enclosure shall be inspected by the dog control officer, so long as the vicious dog remains, on a semi-annual basis, or at other times when deemed necessary by the dog control officer. 
(3)  Whenever the animal is outside the additional fence or pen provided for in this section: 
a.  It must be attended by the owner; and 
b.  It must be restrained by a secure collar and leash or rope no shorter than eight feet nor longer than ten feet in length and of sufficient strength to prevent escape. 
(4)  No vicious animal shall be allowed outside the owner's property except in emergencies or for normal or necessary medical or health related treatment. 
(5)  No vicious animal shall be chained, tethered, or otherwise tied to any object such as a tree, post or building, outside of its additional fence or pen as provided in this section. 
(6)  An electronic animal confinement system shall not be used to confine an animal classified as vicious. 
(Ord. No. 2010-019, § 4-43, 8-17-2010)  
Sec. 10-84. - Authority of dog control officer when enclosure deemed inadequate. 
When a vicious animal is not properly or securely confined pursuant to the provisions of this article, the supervisor shall order confinement of the animal with a licensed veterinarian or with the animal shelter until the owner in charge of such animal provides an enclosure which complies with the provisions of section 10-83. Provided, however, that if the owner in charge of such animal fails to provide a proper enclosure as provided by section 10-83 within 30 days, such animal shall be disposed of as directed by the supervisor. All costs of feeding and caring for such animal during said confinement shall be paid by the owner, provided however, that the daily cost of confinement at the animal shelter shall not exceed $20.00 per day. 
(Ord. No. 2010-019, § 4-44, 8-17-2010)  
Sec. 10-85. - Penalty. 
Unless otherwise specified in this article, violations of any section of this article are subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 2010-019, § 4-45, 8-17-2010)  
Chapter 14 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to own, regulate, control, etc., cemeteries, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-40 et seq. 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Prerequisites for burial in city cemeteries. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bury the dead in any city cemetery without notice to and consent of the planning director, and without having selected and paid for a plot therein. 
(Code 1971, § 6-1; Code 1992, § 7-1)  
Sec. 14-2. - Damage to property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously damage, deface, remove or destroy any tomb, monument, gravestone or memorial to the dead, or any fence or enclosure about any tomb, monument, gravestone, or memorial, or willfully destroy, remove, cut, break or injure any tree, shrub or plant, within the enclosure of any city cemetery. 
(Code 1971, § 6-2; Code 1992, § 7-2) 
State Law reference— Desecration of tombs, etc., Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-23.1.  
Sec. 14-3. - Unlawful entry—Public cemeteries. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, without proper authority, to enter or to remain or to be present in any public cemetery at any time between one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1971, § 6-3; Code 1992, § 7-3)  
Sec. 14-4. - Same—Private cemeteries. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter, remain or be present in a private cemetery without the owner's written permission at any time between one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1971, § 6-4; Code 1992, § 7-4)  
Sec. 14-5. - Fees for plots and placement of markers. 
(a)  The rate to be charged for cemetery plots in Oak Hill Cemetery and Chapman Cemetery shall be $275.00 per plot for any plot sold from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(b)  Commencing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, the city shall charge a fee of $25.00 per plot for the placement of any permanent grave markers. 
(c)  Permanent grave markers may be placed on graves with the city personnel marking the location for placement of the marker. 
(Ord. of 9-21-1993)  
Chapter 18 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Elections, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-46-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Elections in compliance with state law. 
General municipal elections held in the city shall be conducted pursuant to the provisions of applicable state law. 
(Code 1971, § 7-1; Code 1992, § 2-5) 
State Law reference— Municipal elections, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-46-1 et seq.  
Sec. 18-2. - Election districts; election of councilmember; term of office. 
At the municipal election in 2012, and every four years thereafter, the qualified electors residing in each of the above described districts of the city who are entitled to participate in such election shall elect one councilmember to the city council for that district. Each councilmember so elected shall be a bona fide elector of and must actually reside in the district from which they qualified for election. 
Each such councilmember shall hold office for a period of four years or until a successor shall be elected and qualified or until such councilmember shall resign, die, or move their residence outside of said district or otherwise be removed from office. 
This law shall not affect the duties, rights or tenure of office of the existing members of the city council or the mayor, who shall continue to hold and discharge the duties of said office as is incumbent upon them or as may hereafter be made incumbent upon them by law, until their successors shall be elected and qualified under this law. 
(Code 1971, § 2-2; Code 1992, § 2-3; Ord. of 11-5-1987, § 3; Ord. of 4-21-1992, § 3; Ord. of 4-2-1996, § 3; Ord. No. 2003-031, § 3, 10-7-2003; Ord. No. 2011-024, § 3, 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2011-024, §§ 3, 5, 9-6-2011)  
Sec. 18-3. - Election of mayor; term of office. 
At the municipal election to be held in 2012, and every four years thereafter, the qualified electors residing in the city who are entitled to participate in such election shall elect the mayor from at large. The mayor shall be a bona fide elector of and must actually reside within the corporate limits of the city. 
The mayor shall hold office for a period of four years or until a successor shall be elected and qualified or until the mayor shall resign, die, or move his/her residence outside of said city or otherwise be removed from office. 
This law shall not affect the duties, rights or tenure of office of the existing members of the city council or the mayor, who shall continue to hold and discharge the duties of said office as is incumbent upon them or as may hereafter be made incumbent upon them by law, until their successors shall be elected and qualified under this law. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1; Code 1992, § 2-4; Ord. of 11-5-1987, § 4; Ord. of 4-21-1992, § 4; Ord. of 4-2-1996, § 4; Ord. No. 2003-031, § 4, 10-7-2003; Ord. No. 2011-024, §§ 4, 5, 9-6-2011)  
Sec. 18-4. - Election districts; descriptions; incorporation of map. 
In accordance with state law and prior agreements resolving civil rights litigation related to voting, the city is hereby divided into seven single member districts to be designated as district 1, district 2, district 3, district 4, district 5, district 6 and district 7. 
The districts are the areas within the city that are enclosed by lines that follow existing corporate limits as of the date of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, centerline of streets, roadways, alleys, railroads or extensions thereof; property lines; streams, creeks and rivers; or other lines as described in the metes and bounds description of district boundaries included as a part of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived as attachment 1 and as shown on the graphic depiction referred to as attachment 2. 
(Code 1992, §§ 2-1, 2-2; Ord. of 11-5-1987, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 4-21-1992, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 4-2-1996, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 2003-031, §§ 1, 2, 10-7-2003; Ord. of 5-4-2004; Ord. No. 2011-024, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-2011) 
Editor's note— Attachment 2 is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city.  
Sec. 18-5. - Candidate qualification fees. 
(a)  A qualification fee in the amount of $50.00 is hereby fixed and imposed upon all candidates seeking election as mayor, except as hereinafter provided for. 
(b)  A qualification fee in the amount of $25.00 is hereby fixed and imposed upon all candidates seeking election as councilmembers, except as hereinafter provided for. 
(c)  Such qualification fee shall be paid to the city clerk and deposited to the general fund at or prior to the time of taking out qualification papers by any such candidates. 
(d)  Any person desiring to qualify who is not financially able to pay the required fee may qualify provided such prospective candidate furnishes the clerk with an affidavit stating that he is financially unable to pay the required fee fixed by this section. 
(Code 1992, § 2-7; Ord. of 5-3-1988, §§ 1—4; Ord. of 6-2-1992, §§ 1—5; Ord. of 6-4-1996, §§ 1—5) 
State Law reference— Establishment of qualification fee, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-46-2.  
Sec. 18-6. - Voting places. 
The following places are hereby designated as voting places for each of the seven election districts in the city. 
(1)  District 1: Prattville Area Chamber of Commerce, 131 N. Court Street. 
(2)  District 2: First Missionary Baptist Church, 192 Seventh Street; Spring Hill AME Zion Church, 303 County Road 4 East. 
(3)  District 3: Saint Joseph Catholic Church, 511 N. Memorial Drive. 
(4)  District 4: Glynwood Baptist Church, 376 McQueen Smith Road North. 
(5)  District 5: Journey Church, 435 Sheila Boulevard. 
(6)  District 6: Trinity United Methodist Church, 610 Fairview Avenue. 
(7)  District 7: Doster Community Center, 424 S. Northington Street. 
(Code 1971, § 7-2; Code 1992, § 2-6; Ord. of 12-8-1988; Ord. of 6-2-1992; Ord. No. 2003-031, § 6, 10-7-2003; Ord. No. 2011-024, § 6, 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2012-014, 5-15-2012 )  
Sec. 18-7. - On-site voting location and poll hours. 
(a)  The city hall council chambers is designated as the voting site for absentee on-site voting. 
(b)  The hours of the polls will be set from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2000-008, 6-6-2000)  
Sec. 18-8. - Electronic vote counting system. 
For all elections held subsequent to the passage of the ordinance from which this section was derived, the use of the DS200 Electronic Vote Counting System, or any subsequent model device that the Autauga County Commission shall utilize which complies with Code of Ala. 1975, § 17-7-21, as amended, and any regulations adopted pursuant thereto, is hereby authorized for the reporting, counting, and tabulating of any and all election results. 
( Ord. No. 2016-A-010, 4-19-2016 )  
Chapter 22 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Alabama Emergency Management Act of 1955, Code of Ala. 1975, § 31-9-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 22-1—22-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Alabama Emergency Management Act of 1955, Code of Ala. 1975, § 31-9-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 22-20. - Organization; purpose. 
The statement of purpose of the emergency management organization is as follows: It is an operational assumption of the civil preparedness program that existing agencies of government will perform emergency activities related to those they perform in normal times. Auxiliary groups will be formed and trained, under the direction and control of the operating department of government they are to support, and nongovernmental groups will be assigned emergency missions, as necessary, to develop a capability to augment or supplement existing agencies of government in responding to emergencies. A basic purpose of the local civil preparedness agency and its director shall be to provide for coordination of the operations of all such governmental and nongovernmental forces in emergencies, and to provide those unique civil preparedness skills and capabilities not available in existing government organizations. The director shall also inform the operating departments of government of those special conditions arising out of a nuclear attack that would call for a modification of traditional operating techniques. 
(Code 1992, § 9-2; Ord. of 2-16-1982(2))  
Sec. 22-21. - Emergency proclamation—Authorized. 
Whenever the mayor, or in the event of the mayor's absence or inability to act, the president of the council, determines that an emergency exists as a result of mob action or other civil disobedience causing danger of injury to or damage to persons or property, such official shall have power to impose by proclamation any or all of the following regulations necessary to preserve the peace and order of the city: 
(1)  To impose a curfew upon all or any portion of the city thereby requiring all persons in such designated curfew areas to forthwith remove themselves from the public streets, alleys, parks or other public places; provided, however, that physicians, nurses and ambulance operators performing medical services, utility personnel maintaining essential public services, firefighters and city authorized or requested law enforcement officers and personnel may be exempted from such curfew. 
(2)  To order the closing of any business establishments anywhere within the city for the period of the emergency, such businesses to include, but not be limited to, those selling gasoline or firearms. 
(3)  To designate any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking area closed to motor vehicles and pedestrian traffic. 
(4)  To call upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and organizations within or without the city to assist in preserving and keeping the peace within the city. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1.1; Code 1992, § 9-3) 
State Law reference— Authority, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-82.  
Sec. 22-22. - Same—When effective. 
The proclamation of emergency issued by the mayor shall become effective upon its issuance and dissemination to the public by appropriate news media. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1.2; Code 1992, § 9-4)  
Sec. 22-23. - Same—Termination; extending. 
Any emergency proclaimed in accordance with this division shall terminate after 48 hours from the issuance thereof, or upon the issuance of a proclamation determining an emergency no longer exists, whichever occurs first; provided, however, such emergency proclamation may be extended for such additional periods of time as determined necessary by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1.3; Code 1992, § 9-5)  
Sec. 22-24. - Same—Violating orders. 
Any person who shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with the orders of duly authorized law enforcement officers or personnel charged with the responsibility of enforcing the proclamation of emergency authorized herein shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1.4; Code 1992, § 9-6)  
Secs. 22-25—22-51. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Alarm system installers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-1A-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-52. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm business means the business by an individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved, or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure, or facility. 
Alarm system means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to signal the occurrence of fire or activation of an extinguishing system requiring urgent attention and to which the fire department is expected to respond. 
Alarm user or user means the person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure, or facility wherein an alarm system is used or maintained. 
Appellant means any person who perfects an appeal pursuant to this article. 
Applicant means any person filing an application for any permit or license required by this article. 
Communications center means the county emergency management communications facility used to receive emergency and general information from the public to be dispatched to the fire department personnel. 
Designated trunk lines means a trunk line used for receiving automatic dialers. 
False alarm means an alarm signal electing a response by the fire department, when a situation requiring a response by the fire department does not in fact exist, but does not include an alarm signal caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm business operator or the alarm user. 
Notice refers to written notice, given by personal service upon the addressee, or given by depositing said notice in the United States Postal Service mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the person to be notified at his last known address. 
Subscriber means any person who purchases, leases, contracts for, or otherwise obtains services for the maintenance of an alarm system from an alarm business. 
(Code 1992, § 6-201; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 1)  
Sec. 22-53. - Cumulative remedies. 
All remedies granted in this article shall be cumulative and the use of one or more by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 6-214; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 14)  
Sec. 22-54. - User instructions. 
(a)  Every alarm business selling, leasing, or furnishing to any user an alarm system which is installed on the premises located in the area subject to this article shall furnish the user with instructions to enable the user to operate the alarm system properly and to obtain service for the alarm system at any time from the alarm business. 
(b)  Any commercial, church, and institutional alarm user shall instruct two designated employees in the use of the alarm system and shall enable an employee, on duty or available within one hour to operate the alarm system properly at any time. Such employee's name and telephone numbers shall be posted at the main entrance to the premises and shall be readable from an area accessible to fire department personnel. Such name and telephone number shall be filed with the communication center within two working days. 
(Code 1992, § 6-202; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 2)  
Sec. 22-55. - Alarm installation and regulations. 
All alarm businesses, in order to have their system monitored by the communications center, must install the system in accordance with all local and state codes recognized and enforced by the city. All alarm businesses must be qualified to install said equipment. 
(Code 1992, § 6-203; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 3)  
Sec. 22-56. - Penalties for false alarms. 
False alarms within the first 30 days after installation of an alarm system shall be allowable. Each false alarm after the first 30 days shall be subject to a fee of $25.00 per alarm call. Payment for alarm calls caused by acts of God will not be assessed and are not payable. 
(Code 1992, § 6-209; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 9)  
Sec. 22-57. - Alarm terminations. 
The following are conditions under which alarm monitoring by the communications center and emergency response by the fire department may be terminated: 
(1)  Anytime an alarm is set off or activated intentionally by any alarm user or any of its officers, agents, or employees, for the purpose of testing the response time of the fire department. 
(2)  After an alarm, the refusal or failure of the user or his designated representative to respond to check the premises with the responding units within one hour of the commencement of the alarm. 
(3)  Anytime the alarm is in the line or alarm position for a period of eight hours or more without being repaired or any attempt made to have it repaired. 
(4)  Any alarm user having excessive false alarms within any 12-month period may be terminated and/or disconnected from connections to the communications center and emergency response by the fire department shall cease. 
(5)  Any other reason that the fire chief finds, for good cause, that is in the best interest of the city. 
(6)  Failure to pay a penalty assessed by section 22-56 within 30 days. 
(Code 1992, § 6-210; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 10)  
Sec. 22-58. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  Repeated false alarms. No person owning, using or possessing an alarm system shall cause or permit the giving of repeated false alarms. 
(b)  Telephone dialer systems. No person shall install, have installed, or operate an automatic telephone dialer that selects an emergency service trunkline to the police department or communications center except to a telephone number for such purpose as specified by the chief of the fire department. 
(c)  Audible alarms. No person shall own an audible alarm system that is not automatically silenced within 30 minutes after being activated unless a new act or circumstance triggers the sensor to activate such alarm. 
(Code 1992, § 6-211; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 11)  
Sec. 22-59. - Notification of alarm system maintenance. 
Any alarm business or user, prior to commencement of work or testing, and upon completion of work or testing on any alarm system monitored by the communications center, shall notify the communications center providing the following information: 
(1)  Proper identification of the alarm business or user and identification of the individual performing work for the alarm business or user. 
(2)  Exact location of the alarm user. 
(3)  Estimated time of completion of work or test. 
(Code 1992, § 6-213; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 13)  
Secs. 22-60—22-76. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 22-77. - Required. 
No person shall install an alarm system that requires the emergency response of fire department services without the applicant first obtaining a permit from the city. No person shall engage in, conduct, or carry on an alarm business without first applying for and receiving an alarm business license prior to obtaining a permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. No person shall engage in, conduct or operate as an alarm agent without first applying for and receiving an alarm agent permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. No person shall possess, own, or use an alarm system without first applying for and receiving an alarm system permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 6-204; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 4)  
Sec. 22-78. - Applications; required information; denials; appeals. 
(a)  Permit application forms. All applications for any permit required by this article shall be filed with the city clerk's office upon such forms as may be prescribed by the chief of the fire department. Said forms shall request only such information as is reasonably necessary to evaluate and act upon the permit for which the application is made. Each application required by this article shall be signed by the applicant if acting as an individual, by a general partner if acting as a partnership, or by the chief executive officer of a corporation, or if a foreign corporation, by the local manager or officer of said corporation designated to sign at the local level. Each application for a permit for an alarm agent or an alarm business shall be accompanied by an application fee of $10.00; provided, however, that no application fee shall be required for the application of a renewal permit as required by the terms of this article. 
(b)  Alarm business and alarm agent permit applications. Every application for an alarm business permit or alarm agent permit shall require fingerprints and photographs of the applicant or agent applying for the application. If such applicant is not a natural person, the chief of the fire department shall request an investigation from the police department as he deems appropriate and necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(c)  Denial of application. The permit applied for shall be denied if: 
(1)  The applicant has knowingly or willfully given any false information of a material nature in connection with the application for a permit applied for hereunder. 
(2)  The applicant has violated or failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article. 
(3)  The applicant has had a similar type permit revoked for good cause within the past year unless the applicant can show a material change in circumstances since the date of said revocation. 
(4)  The applicant has been convicted of any federal or state law or municipal ordinance which reasonably relates to the applicant's character, fitness and responsibility for engaging in the activity for which application is made consistent with regard for public safety. The fire chief shall regard any information received from the chief of the police department as confidential and shall consider the nature and seriousness of the offense, the circumstances surrounding the offense, the number of such offenses, the amount of time that has elapsed since the offense, the age of the applicant at the time of the offense, and any evidence of rehabilitation. 
(d)  Alarm system permit. An alarm system permit shall be required for the person owning, using, or possessing the alarm system. Alarm businesses shall procure and process the applications for their subscribers and submit the completed application to the city clerk's office. Where a proprietor alarm or audible alarm is in operation and not serviced by an alarm business, the application for the permit shall be filed directly by the applicant. Any application for an alarm system permit involving the proposed use of an audible alarm shall be accompanied by the names, addresses and telephone numbers of three individuals who may be contacted in the event the alarm is activated. 
(e)  Appeal from permit denial. Any applicant denied a permit applied for pursuant to the terms of this article may appeal such denial to the city council or by notifying the city clerk in writing of such appeal within 15 days of the denial of such permit. The city council shall conduct a hearing on such appeal within 30 days of notification by the applicant of such appeal, at which time the applicant may appear before the city council and present evidence as to why his application should be approved. The city council may reverse or uphold the denial of any permit applied for hereunder. 
(Code 1992, § 6-205; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 5)  
Sec. 22-79. - Fees; waivers; transferability and revocation of permits. 
(a)  Alarm business permits. The anniversary date of alarm business permits shall be on January 1. Applications for renewals of alarm business permits shall be processed in the same manner as original applications. 
(b)  Alarm agent permits. January 1 of each year shall be the anniversary date for alarm agent permits. Alarm agent permits shall expire three years after issuance and there is hereby imposed a permit fee of $30.00 for such permits, and said fee shall not be prorated nor refunded. Applications for renewals of alarm agent permits shall be processed in the same manner as original application and the fee for such renewal permit shall be $30.00 for each successive three-year period. 
(c)  Alarm system permits. No permit fee shall be imposed for an alarm system permit. Alarm system permits shall expire on the third anniversary date following its issuance. January 1 of the year of issuance shall be considered the original date of issuance and each January 1 thereafter shall be the anniversary date for all such permits. Applications for renewal of permits shall be processed in the same manner as applications for the initial permit. 
(d)  Permit fee waiver. Persons having an alarm system in operation on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall make application for a permit. Such permit fee shall be waived if the application is submitted within 90 days following the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(e)  Transferability. Permits issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferable upon approval of such transfer by the chief of the fire department. 
(f)  Revocation of permits. Permits shall be considered a privilege and not a right of the permittee. Failure of the alarm system to maintain reliability will necessitate the revocation or the cancellation of the permit and discontinuance of service by the city upon due notice to the permittee by first class mail or delivery in person by a designated city employee. In addition to any other punishment, fine, penalty, or fee prescribed herein, the chief of the fire department shall revoke any permit issued pursuant to the terms of this article for the following reasons: 
(1)  The violation of any of the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Where any alarm system actuates excessive false alarms; 
(3)  Where any alarm business permittee or alarm agent permittee is convicted of any federal or state law or municipal ordinance which reasonably relates to the permittee's character, fitness, and responsibility to engage in the business for which a permit has been issued; or 
(4)  For any reason for which an application may be denied under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 6-206; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 6)  
Sec. 22-80. - Notification of permit revocation. 
In the event the chief of the fire department revokes any permit issued under the terms of this article, he shall give notice to the affected permittee of said revocation that shall state the reasons therefor. Said revocation shall be effective immediately if served upon the permittee, or 72 hours after notice of said revocation has been given by depositing the same in the United States Postal Service mail addressed to the permittee at his last known address. Immediately upon revocation, the permittee shall discontinue the activity permitted under the authority of any permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1992, § 6-207; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 7)  
Sec. 22-81. - Appeal from revocation of permit. 
Any permittee whose permit is revoked in accordance with the foregoing sections may appeal such revocation to the city council by giving notice of such appeal to the city clerk within 15 days after the revocation has become effective. When notice of the appeal is properly filed with the city clerk, the revocation shall be stayed pending a determination thereon by the city council that shall act upon such appeal in the same manner as set forth in this article. The city council may uphold or reverse the revocation of the permit after receiving all relevant evidence pertaining to the revocation and the appellant's arguments and evidence presented on appeal. 
(Code 1992, § 6-208; Ord. of 7-2-1991, § 8)  
Chapter 26 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Fire prevention regulations authorized, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-59, 11-43-60; state fire marshal, Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-19-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Authority having jurisdiction (AHJ) means the organization, office, or individual responsible for approving equipment, materials, an installation, or a procedure. 
Company means a group of members usually organized and identified as engine companies, ladder companies, rescue companies, squad companies, multifunctional companies, or ambulance companies. 
False alarm means the willful and knowing initiation or transmission of a signal, message or other notification of an event of fire when no such danger exists. 
Fire alarm means the giving, signaling or transmission to any public fire station, or company or any officer or employee thereof, whether by telephone, spoken word or otherwise, of information to the effect that there is a fire at or near the place indicated by the person giving, signaling, or transmitting such information. 
Fire chief means the chief officer of the fire department serving the jurisdiction or a duly authorized representative. 
Fire code official means the fire chief or other designated authority charged with administration and enforcement of the code, or a duly authorized representative. 
Fire department means an organization providing rescue, fire suppression, emergency medical care, special operations, and related activities. 
Fire department connection means a connection through which the fire department can pump supplemental water into the sprinkler system, standpipe, or other system furnishing water for fire extinguishment to supplement existing water supplies. 
Fire hydrant means a valve connection on a water main for the purpose of supplying water to fire hose or other fire protection apparatus. 
Fire lane means a road or other passageway developed to allow the passage of fire apparatus. A fire lane is not necessarily intended for vehicular traffic other than fire apparatus. 
Fire suppression means the activities involved in controlling and extinguishing fires. 
Fire watch means a temporary measure intended to ensure continuous and systematic surveillance of a building or portion thereof by one or more qualified individuals for the purposes of identifying and controlling fire hazards, detecting early signs of unwanted fire, raising an alarm of fire and notifying the fire department. 
ICC means the International Code Council. 
Incident commander (IC) means the individual in overall command of an emergency incident. 
Key box means a secure, tamperproof device with a lock operable only by a fire department master key, and containing building entry keys and other keys that may be required for access in an emergency. 
NFPA means the National Fire Protection Association. 
Personnel board means a board which the mayor shall select and convene on an as-needed basis. A personnel board is authorized to serve in a quasi-judicial capacity to: 
(1)  Hear grievances and appeals from eligible city employees in accordance with the guidelines established in these policies; and 
(2)  Conduct studies into personnel areas and make recommendations as requested by the city council or mayor. 
Should indicates a recommendation or that which is advised but not required. 
Standard means a document, the main text of which contains only mandatory provisions using the term "shall" to indicate requirements and which is in a form generally suitable for mandatory reference by another standard or code or adoption into law. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-1.5, 4-19-2005)  
Sec. 26-2. - References to standards. 
Unless stated otherwise, all references in this chapter to technical standards are to such standards as now or hereafter adopted.  
Sec. 26-3. - Fire department established. 
There is hereby established a department to be known as the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-1, 4-19-2005) 
State Law reference— Authority of cities to operate a volunteer or paid fire department, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-140.  
Sec. 26-4. - Fire chief—Appointment. 
(a)  The mayor, with approval of the city council, is hereby authorized to appoint a chief of the fire department, who shall serve subject to the supervision and control of the mayor. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department shall be the director of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-2, 4-19-2005)  
Sec. 26-5. - Same—Powers and duties. 
(a)  Subject to the supervision and control of the mayor in all matters, the fire chief shall administer the affairs of the fire department, which shall include the immediate direction and control of the fire and rescue forces. The chief is charged with responsibilities for the prevention, control, and suppression of fires and hazardous incidents and provide emergency medical and rescue services in the city limits. 
(b)  The responsibilities of the fire department shall include, but not be limited to, the activities of fire administration, fire training, fire prevention, firefighting, hydrant installation and maintenance, fire equipment maintenance and operation, emergency medical training and operation, building inspections, building plan review, code enforcement and fire investigation. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-3, 4-19-2005)  
Sec. 26-6. - Bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The fire prevention code of the city shall be enforced by the fire prevention bureau of the fire department, which is established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the fire chief. 
(b)  The fire marshal in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed from the offices of the fire department by the fire chief. The position of fire marshal shall be a noncompetitive position in the city and the holder thereof, while so engaged, shall not forfeit the merit service status that such person held prior to the appointment. 
(c)  The fire chief may detail such members of the fire department as assistant fire marshals, inspectors, and fire prevention specialists as from time to time shall be necessary. 
(d)  A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made monthly to the fire chief and transmitted to the council. Reports of monthly activities shall be compiled for an annual report at the end of the calendar year. Such reports shall contain all proceedings under this article and the fire prevention code, with such statistics as the chief may wish to include therein. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-4, 4-19-2005)  
Sec. 26-7. - Arson investigative branch. 
(a)  Fire department employees assigned to the arson investigative branch by the fire chief are designated as law enforcement officers as defined by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-181, and rule 1.4, Alabama Rules of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  Arson investigators shall maintain public order and investigate the commission or suspected commission of offenses related to arson or fire prevention and are hereby authorized to be armed and empowered with the full authority of law enforcement officers to make arrests and to take other such actions as may be legal, proper and necessary for the enforcement of the laws of the city and state. 
(c)  Arson investigators as law enforcement officers shall meet the minimum standards set out in Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-21-46 and complete the Alabama Peace Officers Standards and Training Commission (A-POST) Law Enforcement Academy and maintain certification as law enforcement officers as required by A-POST. 
(Ord. No. 2006-014, § 10-4.5, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 26-8. - Temporary assignment to the arson investigative branch. 
(a)  Temporary members shall be assigned to the arson investigative branch from the fire department employees established within the fire department's arson investigative branch to assist with investigations and other related duties of the bureau of fire prevention. These members shall be appointed by the fire chief and shall serve on an as-needed basis. 
(b)  These temporary employees shall carry out all duties in accordance with the arson investigative branch SOPs (standard operating procedures) and guidelines and in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-210. 
(Ord. No. 2006-014, § 10-4.6, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 26-9. - Composition; rules, appointment, powers of fire force. 
(a)  Composition and rules. The fire force shall be composed of the fire chief and such other officers, firefighters, firemedics, EMTs and employees as the mayor may determine. The fire chief shall have immediate direction and control of the department and to such rules, regulations, and orders as may be prescribed by the city council. The fire chief shall promulgate all orders, rules and regulations for the government of the fire department. 
(b)  Appointment. The members of the fire department other than the fire chief shall be appointed from the list of eligibles prepared by the fire department and in accordance with such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the personnel board; provided, that in the case of riot, conflagration, or emergency, the fire chief may appoint additional firefighters and officers for temporary service, who need not be in the classified service. 
(c)  Powers. The fire chief and the chief's assistants are authorized to exercise the power of police officers while responding to, attending or returning from an emergency call or any incident which could cause harm to the city or its citizens. 
(d)  Certificate of appointment. The fire chief and the chief's assistants shall have issued to each of them a certificate of appointment signed by the mayor in which the date of appointment shall be stated, and such certificate shall be each such person's commission. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-5, 4-19-2005)  
Sec. 26-10. - Nonemergency or post-emergency service and fees therefor. 
(a)  The city fire department may provide fire protection equipment for standby service for nonemergency or post-emergency instances if necessary after the normal fire service has ceased. 
(b)  The city shall charge a fee for the city fire department's services at the rate of $200.00 per hour for each company used in the operation. The charges for standby service shall be computed from the time the company leaves the fire station until the time of its return to the station and its placement back into service. 
(c)  The city, for its fire department's service, shall charge an additional fee for foam, chemicals, dirt, pipes, breathing air and the costs of any necessary technical or expert to control or assist in the incident, or any other extraordinary or like material or service needed, to restore the area to its original, before the incident, condition. 
(d)  The involved company or its legal entity, individual, or owner shall reimburse the city for all losses and damage to equipment while being used in connection with providing fire suppression and standby service; and the involved party shall indemnify the city, its fire department officers, agents and employees from all claims for damages or loss in its failure to prevent, control or extinguish any of the involved material, which shall be beyond the control of such officer, agent or employee. 
(e)  The billing for the services shall be by and through the city fire department, which shall forward bills for all services and charges, immediately after the incident, to the appropriate party. All monies collected shall be deposited into a city designated account. 
(f)  No charges shall be imposed for equipment or material in any case where the city fire department is aiding another paid fire department (e.g., federal, state, county or municipal) which has a reciprocal agreement for such service. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-6, 4-19-2005) 
State Law reference— False fire alarms, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-10-8.  
Sec. 26-11. - Service calls outside corporate limits of the city. 
Firefighting service shall be limited to the corporate limits subject to this section. The fire department is not authorized to answer or respond to any call for firefighting service outside the city's corporate limits except under the following conditions and circumstances: 
(1)  When requested by another municipal fire department, a volunteer department organized and existing under the laws of this state, or a state or federal fire department or a bona fide law enforcement agency, to render mutual aid to such department or agency. The city fire department will respond, if in the discretion of the chief, or in his absence the officer in charge, shall determine that it is in the best interest of the city to provide said assistance and provided personnel and equipment are available to meet the fire protection needs of the city after the dispatch of equipment and personnel for said assistance is made. 
(2)  When, in the opinion of the chief, or the officer in charge in the absence of the chief, there exists an actual danger or the real threat of danger to: 
a.  The residents of the city or to property located within the corporate limits of the city. 
b.  Property owned or leased by the city or any of its departments, agencies, commissions, boards or authorities wherever located. 
c.  The students, teachers or other personnel or property of any school including Prattville High School and the Autauga County Vocational School, or work or training center located in the police jurisdiction of the city. 
(3)  This section is not intended nor shall be interpreted to create an obligation on the part of the city to provide fire protection services outside the city limits. 
(4)  The fire department will respond and answer calls for fire protection services to any and all legal entities that have contracted fire protection services by written agreement with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-019, § 10-7, 4-19-2005)  
Secs. 26-12—26-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Fire prevention regulations authorized, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-59, 11-43-60; state fire marshal, Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-19-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-41. - Purposes. 
The purposes of this chapter are to extinguish and prevent fires and to compel citizens to render assistance to the fire department through training and public relations in case of need and to establish, regulate the size, materials and construction of buildings, fences and other structures hereafter erected, and to require the same to be done in such manner as public safety and convenience may require, to remove or require to be removed, any building or structure or addition thereto which by reason of dilapidation, defect of structure or other cause, may have become dangerous to life or property or which may be erected contrary to law, to establish and designate from time to time fire limits within which limits, wooden buildings shall not be constructed, removed, added to or enlarged and to direct that any future buildings within such limits shall be constructed as required in the codes and regulations herein adopted by the city. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-8)  
Sec. 26-42. - Code adopted; penalty. 
The International Fire Code, 2015 edition as revised, consisting of chapters 1—67 and Appendices A—I, K and L published by the International Code Council, Inc., at least one copy of which is on file in the city clerk's office, which provides rules and regulations for fire prevention standards be and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. When a provision of the International Fire Code is in conflict with a provision of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standards, and the conflict relates to life and building safety performance requirements, the fire chief shall have the discretion to determine which provision shall apply. 
Amendments to the International Fire Code are as follows: 
506.1.3 All devices shall be installed and maintain at the owner/occupants expense. 
507.5.1.1.1 Hydrant for fire sprinkler systems. Buildings equipped with a FDC (Fire Department Connection) for a fire sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903 shall have a fire hydrant within 150 feet of the FDC. 
Exception: The distance shall be permitted to exceed 150 feet where approved by the fire code official. 
903.3.7.1 Where sprinkler systems are installed and are required by code to have an (FDC) Fire Department Connection, all F.D.C.'s shall be 2½ inch national Standard Threads. 
903.3.8 Fire Department Connections. Where sprinkler systems are installed and are required by code to have an (FDC) Fire Department Connection, all F.D.C.'s shall be 2½ inch national Standard Threads. 
903.4.2 Alarms. An approved audible and visual device, located on the exterior of the building in an approved location, shall be connected to each automatic sprinkler system. Such sprinkler water-flow alarm devices shall be activated by water flow equivalent to the flow of a single sprinkler of the smallest orifice size installed in the system. Where a fire alarm system is installed, actuation of the automatic sprinkler system shall actuate the building fire alarm system. 
904.11.6.4 Commercial Hoods with Fire Suppression Systems. All systems shall be installed and maintained in accordance with applicable codes and standards. All new installations, annual and semi-annual services (and when required by code or manufacturer recommendations) shall install new fusible links and CO2 cartridges with devices dated and stamped by the manufacture, with the same year date as the installation or service is taking place. 
2306.2.2 Above-ground tanks located inside buildings . Above-ground tanks for the storage of class I, II, IIIA liquid fuels are prohibited within the entire city. 
2306.2.3 Above-ground tanks located outside buildings. Above-ground tanks for the storage of class I, II, IIIA liquid fuels outside of buildings are prohibited except in the following locations. Aboveground storage tanks shall be allowed at the Prattville Airport and in properties zoned M2 and such storage is used in conjunction with those facilities and is necessary for manufacturing and/or processing for those facilities. In M2 properties, aboveground storage shall be allowed only in Protected above Ground Tanks as defined in NFPA 30. 
The applicant shall provide to the City Planning/Building Department, City Engineer, Fire Chief, and Director of the Autauga County Emergency Management detailed plans and specifications showing compliance to the most current edition of NFPA 30 and compliance with the currently adopted International Fire Code as well as any other state and/or federal laws that may apply. Inspections by the above stated departments shall be conducted to verify code compliance before storage tanks may be filled with any product. 
Appendix B is amended as follows: 
Section B105 - FIRE-FLOW REQUIREMENTS FOR BUILDINGS 
B105.1 One- and two-family dwellings, Group R-3 and R-4 buildings and townhouses. The minimum fire-flow and flow duration requirements for one- and two-family dwellings, Group R-3 and R-4 buildings and townhouses shall be specified in Chapter 26 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION, Sec. 26-100. - Installation requirements of the city ordinance. 
Delete Table B105.1(1). 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-9; Ord. No. 2011-022, 7-5-2011; Ord. No. 2016-007, 3-15-2016 ) 
State Law reference— Adoption by reference, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8.  
Sec. 26-43. - Modifications. 
The fire chief shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code adopted by this article upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or duly authorized agent of the owner or lessee, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification, when granted or allowed, and the decision of the fire chief thereon shall be entered upon the records of the fire department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-10)  
Sec. 26-44. - Appeals. 
Whenever the fire chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a license or permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code adopted by this article do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal the decision of the fire chief to the city council within 30 days from the date of the decision. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-11)  
Sec. 26-45. - Investigation of fires. 
The fire marshal's office of the fire department shall investigate the cause, origin, and circumstance of every fire occurring in the city which is of suspicious nature or which involves loss of life or injury to persons or by which property has been destroyed or substantially damaged. Such investigation shall begin immediately upon the occurrence of such fire and the fire chief shall be immediately notified of the facts. The fire chief shall take charge immediately of the physical evidence and shall notify the proper law enforcement officials and the state fire marshal, if needed. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-12)  
Sec. 26-46. - Building permits and plan checking. 
Prior to the issuance of any building permit for building construction, building modification, building alteration, etc., a member of the fire department and/or the fire marshal, as delegated by the fire chief, shall review all plans submitted to evaluate the same for fire safety features, such as vertical separation, exits, exit corridors and stairs, combustibility of materials to be used, fire extinguishing apparatus and exit lights, and exitways and entranceways to and from such property. Single-family residences shall be exempt from this requirement, unless the owner or builder requests a fire department evaluation. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-13)  
Secs. 26-47—26-75. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-022, adopted July 5, 2011, repealed §§ 26-47—26-51, which pertained to fire protection equipment, and derived from Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), §§ 10-14—10-18.  
DIVISION 2. - FIRE SCENE 
 
Sec. 26-76. - Delay by citizens in reporting fires. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to delay reporting immediately any fire or emergency discovered to the fire department (911) or the police department so that emergency vehicles may be dispatched. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-23)  
Sec. 26-77. - Report of fire injury or death. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to notify or delay the notification to the fire chief of a fire injury or death. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-24)  
Sec. 26-78. - Certain acts prohibited at or near fires or emergencies. 
It shall be unlawful to commit any of the following acts at the burning of a building or at any other incident, time, and place where any employee of the fire department is discharging or attempting to discharge an official duty: 
(1)  To possess any flammable, explosive or combustible material or substance, or any device in an arrangement or preparation with intent to willfully and maliciously use such material to set fire to or burn any building or property. 
(2)  To possess, manufacture, or dispose of a fire bomb containing a flammable liquid with a flashpoint of 150 degrees Fahrenheit or less having a wick or similar device capable of being ignited, excluding commercial manufactured devices primarily for the purpose of illumination. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-25) 
State Law reference— Criminal possession of explosives, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-44.  
Secs. 26-79—26-99. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FIRE HYDRANTS 
 
Sec. 26-100. - Installation requirements. 
(a)  All residential subdivisions, commercial developments, shopping centers and apartment developments shall have fire hydrants installed by the developer in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Fire hydrant spacing shall be installed according to the fire flow demand as outlined in accordance with the insurance service office grading schedule for municipal fire protection. 
(2)  Fire hydrants shall be of the type recommended by the American Water Works Association (AWWA), National Fire Protection Association (NFPA), Standard 24, and approved by the public water system supplying such hydrants and the city fire department. 
(3)  Fire hydrants shall be equipped with not less than one 4½-inch outlet and two 2½-inch outlets with national standard threads. All outlets shall be male, with the direction of the discharge parallel to the street served by the hydrant. 
(4)  All fire hydrants shall be connected to and supplied by water mains of not less than six inches in size. The water mains shall meet the specifications established by the American Water Works Association and approved by the public water system supplying the hydrants. 
(5)  For all apartment and residential developments, the fire hydrants shall be placed at each street intersection and spaced intermittently not more than 800 feet apart with additional fire hydrants located as necessary to permit all portions of the buildings to be accessed by hose lays of not more than 400 feet. 
(6)  In shopping centers and other commercial developments, fire hydrants shall be spaced not more than 500 feet apart with additional fire hydrants located as necessary so as to permit all portions of the buildings located therein to be accessed by hose lays of not more than 300 feet. 
(7)  In industrial parks or manufacturing developments that are developed with streets, fire hydrants shall be placed at each intersection with intermittent hydrants between intersections spaced not more than 300 feet apart with additional hydrants located as necessary so as to permit all portions of the buildings located therein to be accessed by hose lays of not more than 300 feet. 
(8)  No fire hydrant shall be installed and deemed serviceable that has a fire flow of less than 500 gallons per minute and 20 pounds of residual pressure. 
(9)  The developer shall file with the planning and development department and with the fire department a map indicating the size of the mains, location of hydrants prior to the installation of the mains or the hydrants and prior to the construction of any buildings in any development, which map shall be approved by the fire chief or the chief's designated representative. Additionally, upon completion, the developer shall file with the appropriate city department three sets of as-built plans of fire hydrants and mains. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued in any area affected by this section for any development that has failed to comply with the terms and conditions of this section. All water mains and fire hydrants shall be installed under pressure, and ready for firefighting use, before any sheathing may be installed on walls and on roofs of any buildings in a development. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-26)  
Sec. 26-101. - Breaking, defacing, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to break, deface or carry away without lawful authority any part of any fireplug or hydrant. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-27) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-20.  
Sec. 26-102. - Unauthorized tapping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, except in case of a fire under the direction of the fire department or by direction of some officer or person legally authorized to so direct, to open any fireplug or hydrant and allow the water to escape. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-28.1)  
Secs. 26-103—26-132. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - FIRE LANES 
 
Sec. 26-133. - Creation and maintenance. 
It shall be the duty of the fire department or its authorized representative to create or establish and maintain, at the property owner's expense, such fire lanes as may be required for the protection of commercial properties within the city limits. It shall be unlawful to block or obstruct any designated fire lane when such lane is located on public property or private property dedicated to public use. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-29)  
Secs. 26-134—26-164. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - FIRE PRECAUTIONS 
 
Sec. 26-165. - Sale, purchase, possession, and explosion of fireworks and pyrotechnics. 
(a)  Definition. When used in this division, the term "fireworks" or "pyrotechnics" means and includes one or more of the following: 
(1)  Sparklers; 
(2)  Squibs; 
(3)  Rockets; 
(4)  Firecrackers; 
(5)  Roman candles; 
(6)  Fire balloons; 
(7)  Signal lights; 
(8)  Torpedoes; 
(9)  Torpedo caps; 
(10)  Railroad and track torpedoes; 
(11)  Flashlight compositions; 
(12)  Firecrackers of all kinds; or 
(13)  Other devices or compositions which are used to obtain visible or audible pyrotechnic displays. 
(b)  Possession. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to have in possession, keep, store, use, manufacture, sell, offer for sale, give away, or handle any pyrotechnics within the corporate limits of the city; provided, however, nothing in this section shall be held to apply to articles manufactured for use as signaling devices and used as such in the operation of railroads, boats, or airplanes, or other required emergency purposes; and provided further, nothing in this section shall be held to apply to a normal supply of flashlight compositions in the hands of photographers or dealers in photographic supplies. Exceptions: This section shall be forever waived for the purpose of the annual Independence Day celebration sponsored by the city at Stanley-Jensen Stadium. 
(c)  Police jurisdiction. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in possession, keep, store, use, manufacture, sell, offer for sale, give away or handle any pyrotechnics within the police jurisdiction of the city; provided, however, nothing in this subsection shall be held to apply to articles manufactured for use as signaling devices and used as such in the operation of railroads, boats or airplanes or other required emergency purposes, and provided further that notice in this subsection shall be held to apply to a normal supply of flashlight composition in the hands of photographers or dealers in photographic supplies. However, within the police jurisdiction, from June 20 through July 5 of each year and December 19 of each year through January 2 of the succeeding year, such period is excepted from this subsection within the police jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-30) 
State Law reference— Fireworks, Code of Ala. 1975, § 8-17-210 et seq.; fireworks dealer's license, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-102.  
Sec. 26-166. - Barbeque grills and outdoor cooking. 
Barbeque grills and similar cooking equipment shall not be used or stored on balconies, terraces, or porches of multistory buildings. They shall be used only outside and at a safe distance, not less than ten feet, from the nearest building. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-31)  
Sec. 26-167. - Discharge of sparks, cinders, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or to cause, permit or allow the discharge, emission or escape into the open air in or upon any public place, public street or public avenue, or in or upon the premises or dwelling of another, of any live, hot or burning sparks, cinders or embers or other hot or burning material. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-32)  
Sec. 26-168. - Threatening to burn, damage or destroy property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, knowing the contents thereof to send, deliver or cause to be received by another, or post on the premises of another, any letter or writing or any verbal message threatening to burn, damage or destroy, conditionally or unconditionally, any house, store, shop, barn, or other building, or any vehicle. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-33)  
Sec. 26-169. - Storage of explosives and blasting agents, class I liquids and liquefied petroleum gas restricted. 
The limits referred to in the fire prevention code in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, in which storage of class I liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, and in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, shall be the city limits and the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-34)  
Sec. 26-170. - Cylinder filling stations. 
The fire prevention code is amended by adding section 1701.5.5, "Standards for Installation and Operation of Cylinder Filling Stations (For Motor Fuels Only)." 
1. No cylinder installation shall be made unless Interstate Commerce Commission cylinders are used. ICC cylinders with a water capacity of less than two hundred fifty (250) pounds shall be charged only at bulk storage or cylinder filling plants and not from mobile units such as delivery trucks, except those vehicles specially designed and equipped for cylinder filling, and except those cylinders installed as part of a system using LP gas as a motor fuel or as a fuel for farm equipment such as flame cultivators. ICC cylinders of two hundred fifty (250) water pound capacity or larger may be charged at the installation from mobile units provided they are equipped with fixed liquid level gauging devices, quick filling valves and vapor return valves, all of which are of an approved design, in addition to other required acceptable valves and fittings. 
2. Containers up to two thousand (2,000) water gallon capacities shall be located at least fifty (50) feet from a building, groups of buildings, house trailers and adjoining property lines. These distances may be reduced to not less than ten (10) feet for service station buildings of other than wood construction. Also, in heavily populated or congested area, the authority having jurisdiction (in most cases the Alabama LP Gas Board) shall determine restrictions of individual container capacity, total storage and distance of lien of adjoining property, as well as other reasonable protective measures. 
3. Container foundations shall be of substantial masonry or other noncombustible material. Containers shall be mounted on saddles that shall permit expansion and contraction, and shall provide against the excessive concentration of stresses. Corrosion protection shall be provided for tank mounting areas. Structural metal container supports shall be protected against fire in an approved manner. This protection is not required on prefabricated storage and pump assemblies, mounted on a common base, with container bottom not more than twenty-four (24) inches above ground and whose water capacity is two thousand (2,000) gallons or less if the piping connected to the storage and pump assembly is sufficiently flexible to minimize the possibility of breakage or leakage in the event of failure of the container supports. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58-93, 8.5(b)3.) 
4. Piping shall be wrought iron or steel (black or galvanized), brass or copper pipe; or seamless copper, brass or steel tubing and shall be suitable for a minimum pressure of two hundred fifty (250) psig. Pipe joints may be screwed, flanged, brazed or welded. The use of aluminum alloy piping or tubing is prohibited. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58.94, 8.8(c).) 
5. All piping shall be tested after assembly and proved free from leaks at not less than normal operating pressures. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58.94, 8.8(g).) 
6. Piping may be underground, aboveground, or a combination of both. It shall be well supported and protected against physical damage and corrosion. Piping laid beneath driveways shall be installed to prevent physical damage by vehicles. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58-94, 8.8(b).) 
7. All shut-off valves (liquid or gas) shall be suitable for liquefied petroleum gas service and designed for not less than the maximum pressure to which they may be subjected. Valves that may be subjected to container pressure shall have a rated working pressure of at least two hundred fifty (250) psig. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58-94, 8.8(d).) 
8. All materials used for valve seats, packing, gaskets, diaphragms, etc., shall be resistant to the action of LP gas. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58-94, 8.8(e).) 
9. An excess flow check valve and manual shut-off valve shall be installed in the liquid line at the outlet of the storage tank. 
10. An excess flow check valve and manual shut-off valve shall be installed at the dispensing hosepipe connection. 
11. Fittings shall be steel, malleable iron or brass having a minimum working pressure of two hundred fifty (250) psig. Cast iron pipe fittings, such as ells, tees, and unions shall not be used. (According to NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, 58-94, 8.5(f).) 
12. Storage tanks shall be properly grounded. 
13. Storage container, piping, pump, dispensing hose and scales shall be adequately protected from physical damage at trailer parks and similar locations by a chain-link fence of not less than four (4) feet in height, or least [sic] three (3) feet from the installation, and having an entrance-exit gate of the same height. Such facilities at a service station shall be protected from physical damage by such devices as railroad crossties, utility poles and a chain-link fence of not less than four (4) feet in height, except in reference to a self-contained installation unit, in which case no fence is required. 
14. Each cylinder filling station shall be provided with at least one (1) portable fire extinguisher of the dry chemical type with a minimum 8-B, Crating. 
15. All ICC cylinders of less than two hundred fifty (250) water pound capacity shall be charged by weight only except those cylinders into which is dispensed fuel for motor fuel purposes. 
16. No cylinder designed to be equipped with a safety cap shall be removed from a dealer's or agent's premises until such cap is properly installed, except when a safety guard or shield is an integral part of the cylinder. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-35)  
Sec. 26-171. - Routes for transportation of explosives and blasting agents. 
The routes established for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 31; 
(2)  U.S. Highway 82; 
(3)  U.S. Highway 82 bypass; 
(4)  Jensen Road; 
(5)  County Road No. 4 from Jensen Road to U.S. Highway 31 south; and 
(6)  Doster Road from U.S. Highway 31 south to the Doster Road cutoff. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-36)  
Sec. 26-172. - Routes for transportation of hazardous chemicals, etc. 
The routes established for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 31; 
(2)  U.S. Highway 82; 
(3)  U.S. Highway 82 bypass; 
(4)  Jensen Road; 
(5)  County Road No. 4 from Jensen Road to U.S. Highway 31 south; and 
(6)  Doster Road from U.S. Highway 31 south to the Doster Road cutoff. 
(Ord. of 3-19-2009(02), § 10-37)  
Chapter 30 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
