No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 55 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  On U.S. 82 bypass from U.S. 31 (Memorial Drive) to west city limits. 
(2)  On Alabama Highway 6 from U.S. 31 (Memorial Drive) to Cobbs Ford Road. 
(Code 1971, § 17-38; Code 1992, § 18-30; Ord. No. 2001A-016, § 18-30, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 2008-022, 11-4-2008)  
Sec. 62-78. - Fifty miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 50 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: on Autauga County Road No. 2 from the east city limits westerly toward the city to Pine Creek. 
(Code 1971, § 17-39; Code 1992, § 18-31; Ord. No. 2008-022, 11-4-2008)  
Sec. 62-79. - Forty-five miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 45 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  On Cobbs Ford Road/Main Street from the east city limits to U.S. 31; 
(2)  On U.S. 31 (Memorial Drive) from the north city limits to the south city limits; 
(3)  On Alabama Highway No. 14 (Selma Highway) from 500 feet west of Maple Street to the west city limits; 
(4)  On Alabama Highway No. 14 (Main Street) from 200 feet east of Pratt Street to U.S. 31 (Memorial Drive); 
(5)  McQueen Smith Road; 
(6)  On Alabama Highway No. 206 (Fourth Street) from the west city limits to Autauga Creek; 
(7)  On Autauga County Road No. 57 (Lower Kingston Road) from the north city limits southerly toward the city for a distance of 0.30 mile; 
(8)  On Alabama Highway No. 14 (Fairview Avenue) from Montview Court to the east city limits; 
(9)  Doster Road from U.S. 31 (Memorial Drive) to Shady Hill Road; 
(10)  On Jensen Road from the intersection of U.S. 82 bypass south to the city limits; 
(11)  On Bridge Creek Road beginning at the intersection of Upper Kingston Road north to the city limits; 
(12)  On County Road No. 4 (east of Washington Ferry) from the east city limits to the west city limits. 
(Code 1971, § 17-40; Code 1992, § 18-32; Ord. No. 99-005, 2-2-1999; Ord. No. 2001A-016, § 18-32, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 2008-022, 11-4-2008)  
Sec. 62-80. - Forty miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 40 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: on Alabama Highway No. 14 (Fairview Avenue) from U.S. 31 to Montview Court. 
(Code 1971, § 17-41; Code 1992, § 18-33; Ord. of 8-15-1978; Ord. No. 2001A-016, § 18-33, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 2008-022, 11-4-2008)  
Sec. 62-81. - Thirty-five miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 35 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway No. 206 (Fourth Street) from Autauga Creek to Main Street; 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 14 (Selma Highway/Washington Street) from 500 feet west of Maple Street to the junction of Alabama Highway No. 206 (Main Street); 
(3)  On Alabama Highway No. 14 (Washington and Main Streets) to 200 feet east of Pratt Street; 
(4)  On Autauga County Road No. 57 (Lower Kingston Road) beginning at a point 0.30 mile south of the north city limits to the junction with Alabama Highway No. 206 (Fourth Street); 
(5)  On Washington Ferry Road from Alabama Highway No. 14 (Selma Highway) south to the city limits; 
(6)  Wetumpka Street; 
(7)  Gin Shop Hill Road; 
(8)  Gardner Road; 
(9)  On Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive beginning at the northernmost intersection of Wilberforce Avenue north to the city limits; 
(10)  On Upper Kingston Road beginning at the intersection of Woodland Acres Drive north to the city limits; 
(11)  Durden Road; 
(12)  Doster Road from Shady Hill Road to Mobile Drive; 
(13)  On County Road No. 4 (west of Washington Ferry) from the city limits to the eastern city limits; 
(14)  Old Ridge Road from Alabama Highway No. 14 to the north city limits; 
(15)  South Industrial Parkway. 
(Code 1971, § 17-42; Code 1992, § 18-34; Ord. No. 2001A-016, § 18-34, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 2008-022, 11-4-2008)  
Sec. 62-82. - Thirty miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 30 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  On Autauga County Road No. 57 beginning at a point 0.30 mile south of the north city limits southerly toward the city for a distance of 1.80 miles to the junction with Alabama Highway No. 206; 
(2)  On Sixth Street beginning at the intersection of Memorial Drive and Sixth Street west to North Northington, a distance of 1.10 miles; 
(3)  On North Chestnut Street beginning at the intersection of Wilburforce Street and North Chestnut, north to the city limits, a distance of 1.10 miles; 
(Code 1971, § 17-43; Code 1992, § 18-35; Ord. of 8-15-1978; Ord. No. 2008-022, 11-4-2008)  
Sec. 62-83. - Twenty-five miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 25 miles-per-hour on any streets or alleys other than those specifically mentioned or set out in this division. 
(Code 1971, § 17-44; Code 1992, § 18-36)  
Sec. 62-84. - Fifteen miles-per-hour zones. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 15 miles-per-hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  Court Street from Main Street to 3rd Street; 
(2)  Main Street from Chestnut Street to Court Street. 
(Ord. No. 2003-028, 9-16-2003)  
Sec. 62-85. - Racing. 
Any person who engages in or participates in a race upon the streets in any motor vehicle, whether exceeding the speed limit or not, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-45; Code 1992, § 18-37)  
Secs. 62-86—62-113. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - TRUCK ROUTES 
 
Sec. 62-114. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Deviating truck means a truck which leaves from, or enters, a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
Prohibited routes means streets or sections of streets within the city upon which trucks are prohibited from traveling or operating. 
Truck means any vehicle or combination of vehicles together, including trailers and truck tractors, with trailer attached and designed or operated for the transportation of property and the transporting capacity of which is 1½ tons or more. 
Truck route means a way over certain streets and highways, designated as a truck route by appropriate city, state or federal signs, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the city shall operate. 
(Code 1971, § 17-60; Code 1992, § 18-40; Ord. of 1-4-1983)  
Sec. 62-115. - Established. 
The following routes are established as truck routes: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 82; 
(2)  Alabama Highway No. 14; and 
(3)  U.S. Highway 31. 
(Code 1971, § 17-61; Code 1992, § 18-41; Ord. of 1-4-1983; Ord. of 2-15-1983(1); Ord. No. 2015-046, 12-15-2015 )  
Sec. 62-116. - Prohibited. 
The following streets or sections of streets are hereby designated prohibited routes because of weight restrictions and other conditions deemed hazardous: 
(1)  Bridge Street between Maple Street and Main Street; and 
(2)  Maple Street between Bridge Street and Washington Street. 
( Ord. No. 2017-007, 5-2-2017 ) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly repealed by Ord. No. 2017-006 , adopted Apr. 4, 2017.  
Sec. 62-117. - Operation of trucks. 
(a)  All trucks in the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes established by this division, and on other streets over which truck travel is permitted by the terms of this division as follows: 
(1)  A deviating truck shall operate inside the city only for the purpose of loading and unloading, proceeding to or from a truck route upon originating or terminating a trip. Drivers of trucks shall request, in advance, assistance from the police department whenever this is needed due to length of truck, width of truck, or type of cargo being hauled; and 
(2)  All trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest feasible direction over streets to a truck route as established by this division. 
(b)  This article shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city; 
(2)  The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city, public utilities, or any contractor or materialman, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities within the city; or 
(3)  The operation of trucks upon any detour established by the police department in any case. 
(Code 1971, § 17-63; Code 1992, § 18-43; Ord. of 1-4-1983)  
Sec. 62-118. - Signs to be posted. 
The chief of police shall cause all truck routes and those streets upon which truck traffic is not feasible to be clearly marked by signs posted to give notice thereof. 
(Code 1971, § 17-64; Code 1992, § 18-44; Ord. of 1-4-1983)  
Sec. 62-119. - Weigh-in. 
Any patrol officer of the police department shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle not proceeding over a truck route or street over which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining the applicability of this division to such vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 17-65; Code 1992, § 18-45; Ord. of 1-4-1983)  
Secs. 62-120—62-136. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate parking, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-1; parking in violation of city ordinances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-152; liability of owners and lessors of vehicles for municipal parking violations, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5-152, 32-5-152.1. 
 
Sec. 62-137. - Parking to conform to markings and signs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in such person's name, or owned or operated by such person, or in such person's possession, or under such person's control, to be or remain in any space or area in which parking is prohibited, as designated by proper marking with yellow paint or by sign, or in a time-limit parking area for a longer period of time than that designated by proper marking or a sign, or in any space or area in which parking is provided exclusively for the handicapped as designated by proper marking or sign, unless such vehicle is authorized for parking in a handicapped zone, as evidenced by a decal on the vehicle, or to park in any manner other than that indicated by proper marking or sign. 
(Code 1971, § 17-53; Code 1992, § 18-50; Ord. of 6-5-1984(2)) 
State Law reference— Obedience to traffic-control devices, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-31.  
Sec. 62-138. - Parking of trucks, tractors, etc.—In certain areas. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, except while loading or unloading, any truck larger than 1½ tons, any tractor, trailer or any tractor-trailer combination, upon any street or in any area of the city which is zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-4. 
(Code 1971, § 17-54; Code 1992, § 18-51; Ord. of 2-15-1983(2))  
Sec. 62-139. - Same—With certain capacities of flammable liquids. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to store or park for any purpose, except while loading and unloading, any cargo tank, tank truck or trailer, tractor and trailer combination, or any other tank vehicle having a capacity in excess of 100 gallons for kerosene, gasoline, diesel fuel, propane, butane or any other flammable liquid having a flashpoint of below 70 degrees Fahrenheit within the city, unless written permission has first been obtained from the fire department. 
(Code 1971, § 17-55; Code 1992, § 18-52)  
Chapter 66 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to construct, etc., Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-3, 11-48-4 et seq., 11-50-50 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Waterworks board. 
(a)  There is hereby created a waterworks board, which department is charged with the duty of operating the water system of the city. 
(b)  With regard to sanitary sewer service, the board shall: 
(1)  Furnish such water as may be necessary for the flushing of the sewer system after the discharge of sewage therein. 
(2)  Render bills for the applicable sanitary sewer service charges to the occupants of all properties connected to the sewer system and use every reasonable effort to collect such bills under procedures established in this chapter. 
(3)  Employ such personnel as may be necessary for these purposes. 
(4)  Not less often than once during each calendar month, render to the city a report showing in reasonable detail the total amount of sanitary sewer service charges collected by the board since the period covered by the preceding monthly report. 
(Code 1971, § 19-1; Code 1992, § 13-1) 
State Law reference— Waterworks board, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-234.  
Secs. 66-2—66-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 66-21. - Water service outside city limits restricted. 
No service for water shall be allowed beyond the city limits without a specific resolution and approval by the city council. Such resolution shall set and establish an amount, including but not limited to fees and costs, as will compensate the city for a portion of the costs for capital improvements and construction of the facilities necessary to render said service. 
(Code 1992, § 13-13; Ord. of 11-5-1991)  
Secs. 66-22—66-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to operate sewer system, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-50 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 66-46. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accidental discharge means any release of wastewater that, for any unforeseen reason, fails to comply with any prohibition or limitation in this article. 
Act or the Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (P.L. 92-500), as amended by the Clean Water Act of 1977 (P.L. 95-217), and as further amended (33 USC 1251 et seq.). 
Approval authority means the director of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management (ADEM). 
Authorized representative of industrial user means: 
(1)  A principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president if the industrial user is a corporation; 
(2)  A general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; 
(3)  A duly authorized representative of the individual designated above if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates. 
Biochemical oxygen demand or BOD means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius (68 degrees Fahrenheit) expressed in terms of weight and volume (milligrams per liter). 
Building sewer or house connection means the connecting pipe from a building to the sanitary sewer. 
Categorical standard means national categorical pretreatment standard or pretreatment standard. 
City means the City of Prattville, Alabama. Activities attributable to the city shall be the responsibility of the city council or any city employee delegated by the city council to act for the city. 
Color means what is considered to be the true color of the light transmitted by a waste solution after removing suspended material including pseudocolloidal particles. 
Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and wastewater. Combined sewers are not permitted by ADEM policy. 
Constituents means the specific compounds and components that comprise the wastewater. 
Control authority means the approval authority defined in section 66-1. The term "control authority" shall also apply to the city in accordance with the memorandum of agreement between the state department of environmental management and the city. 
Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Direct discharge means the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the state. 
Domestic wastewater means all liquid and waterborne pollutants, exclusive of unpolluted wastewater, or wastewater or wastes from processes or operations of industrial users. 
Environmental protection agency or EPA means the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or, where appropriate, the term "environmental protection agency" may also be used as a designation for the administrator or the duly authorized official of such agency. 
Flammable is as described in section 66-209(1). 
Grab sample means a sample that is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis with no regard to the flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time. 
Holding tank waste means any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, vacuum pump tank trucks and septic tank haulers. 
Indirect discharge means the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b) or (c) of the Act into the sewerage system, including holding tank waste discharged into the sewerage system. 
Industrial user means any user of the sewerage system who is a source of indirect discharge that does not constitute a discharge of pollutants under regulations issued pursuant to section 402 of the Act. The term "industrial user" means a user who discharges industrial waste into the sewerage system. 
Industrial waste means the liquid or other wastes resulting from any process of industry, manufacture, trade or business or from the development of natural resources. 
Infiltration means the water entering sewers and building sewer connections from the soil through defective joints, broken or cracked pipes, improper connections, manhole walls, etc. The term "infiltration" does not include and is distinguished from inflow. 
Inflow means the water discharged into sewer lines from such sources as roof leaders, cellar and yard area drains, foundation drains, commercial and industrial discharges of unpolluted wastewater, drains from springs and swampy areas, etc. The term "inflow" does not include and is distinguished from infiltration. 
Interference means the inhibition or disruption of the wastewater treatment processes or operations, or acts or discharges which may cause damage to any portion of the sewerage system and/or which contribute to a violation of any requirement of the city NPDES permits. The term "interference" includes interference with sewage sludge use or disposal in accordance with section 405 of the Act or any criteria, guidelines or regulations developed pursuant to SWDA (P.L. 89-272 as amended), the Clean Air Act (P.L. 91-604 as amended) or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to title IV of SWDA) applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the sewerage system. 
Mayor means the administrative officer of the city who is charged with administrative control of all operations of the sewerage system and who is responsible directly to the city. As used herein, the term "mayor" may also include any city employee delegated to act for the city by the mayor or by the city. 
National categorical pretreatment standard, categorical pretreatment standard or pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with section 307(b) and (c) of the Act which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
National pollutant discharge elimination system or NPDES permit means a permit to discharge wastewater issued pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
New source means any source, the construction of which is commenced after the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived, or the publication of proposed regulations prescribing a section 307(c) categorical pretreatment standard which will be applicable to such source if such standard is thereafter promulgated within 120 days of proposal in the federal register. Where the standard is promulgated later than 120 days after proposal, the term "new source" means any source, the construction of which is commenced after the date of promulgation of the standard. 
Normal waste means a waste having average concentrations of 300 milligrams per liter of BOD, or less, and 300 milligrams per liter of suspended solids, or less, as determined by samples taken before entering the sewerage system. 
Person is as defined in section 1-2, excluding this city. 
pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions in moles per liter of solution. Stabilized pH is that determined after a sample of waste has been subjected to natural aeration. 
Pollutant means any solid waste, chemical waste, biological material, radioactive material, thermal waste or industrial, municipal and/or agricultural waste discharged into water. 
Pollution means the manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and/or radiological integrity of water. 
Pretreatment means the reduction of the amounts of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into the sewerage system. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, process changes or other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d). 
Pretreatment requirement means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment, other than a national categorical pretreatment standard imposed on an industrial user. 
Private wastewater disposal system means any facilities for wastewater treatment and disposal not maintained and operated by the city. 
Properly shredded garbage means the organic wastes resulting from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of foods that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights and which is controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
Publicly owned treatment works or POTW means treatment works as defined by section 212 of the Act which are owned, in this instance, by the city. The term "publicly owned treatment works or POTW" includes the wastewater treatment plants and any sewers that convey wastewater to the wastewater treatment plants (i.e., sewerage system). 
Receiving stream means the body of water, stream or watercourse receiving the discharge from a wastewater treatment plant or the body of water, stream or watercourse formed by the effluent from a wastewater treatment plant. 
Sanitary sewage means sewage excluding process wastes from industrial users. 
Sanitary sewer means a public sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility that carries liquid and waterborne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with minor quantities of groundwaters and surface waters that are not intentionally admitted. 
Sewage means a combination of water-carried wastes from residences and industrial users (i.e., wastewater). 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying wastewater. 
Sewerage system means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of wastewater (POTW). 
Significant industrial user or SIU means any industrial user of the city sewerage system who: 
(1)  Has a discharge flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average workday; 
(2)  Has a discharge that is greater than five percent of the hydraulic flow or organic design capacity of the city sewerage system serving the industrial user; 
(3)  Has a discharge that contains toxic pollutants or priority pollutants as defined pursuant to section 307 of the Act or state statutes and rules and regulations; 
(4)  Is found by the city, the approval authority or the EPA to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on the sewerage system, the quality of sludge, the system's effluent quality or air emissions generated by the sewerage system. 
Slug means any discharge of water or wastewater for any duration during which the rate of flow or concentration of any constituent increases to such magnitude so as to adversely affect the operation of the sewerage system or the ability of the city's wastewater treatment plants to meet applicable water quality objectives. 
Standard industrial classification or SIC means a classification of an industry based on its product or service pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget of the federal government, as amended. 
Standard Methods means the analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater published by the American Public Health Association or EPA Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes as per 40 CFR part 136 and amendments thereto. 
Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but which excludes sanitary sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
Stormwater means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
Strength of waste means the concentration of pollutants or substances contained in a liquid waste. 
Suspended solids means the total solid matter that either floats on the surface of or is suspended in water or liquid waste and which is removable by laboratory filtration. 
Toxic pollutant means any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the EPA under provisions of section 307(a) of the Act or by the state. 
24-hour flow proportional composite sample or composite sample means a sample consisting of at least eight portions collected during a 24-hour period or the total period of waste flow if less than 24 hours and in which the sample portions are collected proportionate to the flow and proportionately combined into a single sample. Alternate sampling requirements may be established in a user's SID permit and/or by the control authority. 
Unpolluted wastewater. 
(1)  The term "unpolluted wastewater" means any wastewater that is substantially free of pollutants and is discharged from the following: 
a.  Rain downspouts and drains; 
b.  Footing drains; 
c.  Stormwater and surface water drains; 
d.  Cooling water systems. 
(2)  The term "unpolluted wastewater" shall contain, by definition, none of the following: 
a.  BOD in excess of ten milligrams per liter; 
b.  Suspended solids in excess of ten milligrams per liter; 
c.  Free or emulsified greases or oils; 
d.  Acids or alkalis; 
e.  Phenols or other substances imparting taste or odor to receiving waters; 
f.  Toxic or poisonous substances; 
g.  Noxious or odorous gases; 
h.  Any wastewater with a temperature which exceeds 60 degrees Celsius (140 degrees Fahrenheit) at its introduction into a storm sewer or which exceeds 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) at its introduction into a receiving stream. 
User means any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the sewerage system. 
Wastewater means sewage. 
Wastewater treatment plant means the facilities of the city for treating and disposing of wastewater. 
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently. 
Waters of the state means all bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, within the boundaries of the state. 
(Code 1992, § 13-20; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 1.03)  
Sec. 66-47. - Abbreviations. 
The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
(1)  ADEM: Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
(2)  BOD: biochemical oxygen demand. 
(3)  CFR: Code of Federal Regulations. 
(4)  COD: chemical oxygen demand. 
(5)  EPA: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
(6)  l: liter. 
(7)  mg: milligrams. 
(8)  mg/l: milligrams per liter. 
(9)  NPDES: National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System. 
(10)  O and M: operation and maintenance. 
(11)  OSHA: Occupational Safety and Health Administration. 
(12)  P.L.: Public Law. 
(13)  POTW: publicly owned treatment works. 
(14)  SWDA: Solid Waste Disposal Act. 
(15)  SIU: significant industrial user. 
(16)  SID permit: state indirect discharge permit. 
(17)  SS: suspended solids. 
(18)  USC: United States Code. 
(Code 1992, § 13-21; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 1.02)  
Sec. 66-48. - Purposes; objectives. 
(a)  This article is adopted for the purposes of regulating and controlling the discharge of wastewaters into the sewerage system, to set forth uniform requirements for users of the sewerage system and to enable the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws including, but not limited to, the Clean Water Act of 1977 (P.L. 95-217), as amended; the general pretreatment regulations (40 CFR 403); the Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended; the Clean Air Act, as amended; the Toxic Substances Control Act, as amended; the Alabama Water Pollution Control Act (Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-22-1 et seq.); and rules and regulations of the United States Environmental Protection Agency as amended from time to time. This article provides for the regulation of users of the sewerage system through the issuance of permits to certain nondomestic users and through enforcement of general requirements for all users, authorizes monitoring and enforcement activities, requires user reporting, ensures that existing customers' capacities will not be preempted and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. This article shall apply to all persons who are users of the sewerage system. 
(b)  The objectives of this article are to: 
(1)  Prevent the introduction of pollutants into the sewerage system which will interfere with the operation of the sewerage system or contaminate the resulting sludge. 
(2)  Prevent the introduction of pollutants into the sewerage system which will pass through the sewerage system, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the operation of the sewerage system. 
(3)  Improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludges from the wastewater treatment plants. 
(4)  Provide for equitable distribution of the costs attributable to the construction, operation and maintenance of the sewerage system. 
(5)  Define areas of responsibility and procedures for joint management of the state industrial wastewater pretreatment program as it applies to the city sewerage system by the state department of environmental management and the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-22; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 1.01)  
Sec. 66-49. - Assignment of program responsibilities. 
(a)  Implementation of this article may be either a joint effort by the city and ADEM, or an independent effort by the city under this article or ADEM under its state pretreatment regulations. 
(b)  ADEM shall assume primary responsibility for implementation of actions involving significant industrial users. 
(c)  The city shall assume primary responsibility for implementation of all actions other than those assigned to ADEM under subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1992, § 13-23; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), §§ 15.01—15.03)  
Sec. 66-50. - Reviewing authority; amendment. 
(a)  The city council shall be the reviewing authority for all appeals of actions or administrative determinations made by the city pursuant to the provisions of this article. Notice of an intent to appeal and request for a hearing shall be addressed to the mayor in writing and shall detail the nature of the appeal. An early date for such hearing shall be set by the city council and the appellant promptly notified in writing. The decision of the city council after such hearing shall be final and conclusive and shall be conveyed to the persons involved in writing. 
(b)  The city council expressly reserves the absolute right to amend, modify, rescind or supplement this article with concurrence by ADEM. 
(c)  The city council will adopt and modify from time to time separate rate schedules to supplement this article. 
(Code 1992, § 13-24; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), §§ 13.01—13.03)  
Sec. 66-51. - Authority for inspection. 
(a)  The mayor and other duly authorized employees of the city and ADEM, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, flow measurement, sampling and testing of industrial wastes and other pollutants in accordance with this article. 
(b)  The mayor and other duly authorized employees of the city are authorized to obtain information concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the kinds and sources of discharges to the sewerage system. As required by federal regulations, industrial users must disclose information on processes; however, the city agrees that trade secret information will not be disclosed and will be held confidential. 
(c)  Owners or occupants of premises where wastewater is created or discharged shall allow the mayor and other duly authorized employees of the city and ADEM ready access at all reasonable times to all points on the premises where wastes are discharged into sewers for the purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination or in the performance of any of their duties. 
(d)  The city, its representatives and ADEM shall have the right to set up on the user's property such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling, inspection, compliance monitoring and/or metering operations. 
(e)  Where a user has security measures in force which would require proper identification and clearance before entry into the premises, the user shall make necessary arrangements with such user's security guards so that, upon presentation of suitable identification, personnel from the city, its representatives and ADEM will be permitted to enter, without delay, for the purposes of performing their specific responsibilities. 
(Code 1992, § 13-25; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), §§ 11.01—11.05)  
Sec. 66-52. - Protection of equipment. 
No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, deface, tamper with or remove any equipment or materials which are a part of the sewerage system, or any equipment or materials used by the city or ADEM for the purpose of making waste examinations and waste flow measurements and left upon the premises of a user discharging wastes into the sewerage system. Only persons authorized by the city or ADEM will be allowed to uncover, adjust, maintain and remove such equipment and materials. 
(Code 1992, § 13-26; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 12)  
Secs. 66-53—66-77. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REQUIRED USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 
 
Sec. 66-78. - Restrictions on discharge to outlet other than sanitary sewer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge to any outlet other than a sanitary sewer any domestic or industrial wastes except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article and where an appropriate NPDES permit has been obtained pursuant to section 402 of the Act, or authorized private disposal system approved by the county health department, and provided that the property line for a parcel of land with a private disposal system is not within 150 feet of a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1992, § 13-30; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 2.01; Ord. of 12-6-1994)  
Sec. 66-79. - Required discharge of cooling water to storm sewer. 
Where a storm sewer is adjacent to a property, cooling water which meets the requirements of unpolluted wastewater shall be discharged into the storm sewer in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article, provided that the city determines that sufficient capacity exists in the storm sewer to carry the cooling water without exceeding the design storm drainage capacity of the storm sewer, and where an appropriate NPDES permit has been obtained from ADEM pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
(Code 1992, § 13-31; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 2.02; Ord. of 12-6-1994)  
Sec. 66-80. - Required connection to public sanitary sewer. 
The owners of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley, right-of-way, or private easement, in which there is now located or may in the future be located abutting the property, a public sanitary sewer of the city that discharges to any of the city wastewater treatment plants, which has installed suitable toilet and other facilities therein necessary for the discharge of domestic and/or industrial wastes, is hereby required at the owners' expense to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sanitary sewer, in accordance with provisions of this article within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sanitary sewer is within 150 feet of the property line of the property. Such connections shall be required: 
(1)  When the city determines that a problem exists with an existing private wastewater disposal system which cannot be corrected by any means less than by replacement of a significant portion of the system. 
(2)  Where a public sanitary sewer is available within 150 feet of a property, no new private wastewater disposal systems will be permitted. 
(3)  All new connections to the city sewerage system shall be made in accordance with provisions of division 4 of this article. 
(4)  That all connections to the city sewerage system, after January 1, 1995, shall contain a four-inch or six-inch PVC flow backwater valve with cleanout on each end within two feet of the valve. 
(Code 1992, § 13-32; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 2.03; Ord. of 12-6-1994)  
Sec. 66-81. - Compliance with connection regulations. 
All new connections to the city sewerage system shall be made in accordance with provisions of division 4 of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 13-33; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 2.04)  
Sec. 66-82. - Sewer service outside city limits restricted. 
No service for sewage shall be allowed beyond the city limits without a specific resolution and approval by the city council. Such resolution shall set and establish an amount, including but not limited to fees and costs, as will compensate the city for a portion of the costs for capital improvements and construction of the facilities necessary to render said service. 
(Code 1992, § 13-34; Ord. of 11-5-1991)  
Secs. 66-83—66-107. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL 
 
Sec. 66-108. - Use authorized. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 66-80, such toilet and other facilities necessary for the discharge of domestic and/or industrial wastes shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the requirements of the state, county health department and/or the city and provisions of the standard building code. 
(b)  All connections to the private wastewater disposal system, after January 1, 1995, shall contain a four-inch or six-inch PVC flow backwater valve with cleanout on each end within two feet of the valve. 
(Code 1992, § 13-40; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.01; Ord. of 12-6-1994)  
Sec. 66-109. - Construction permit required; application; furnishing information; payment of fees; percolation tests required. 
Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal system, the owners shall first obtain a written permit from the city. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city that the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the city. At least two percolation tests shall be required within the area of septic tank drain field. Appropriate permit and inspection fees shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Code 1992, § 13-41; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.02)  
Sec. 66-110. - Permit effective upon completion; required inspections. 
A permit for a private wastewater disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the city. The city shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the city when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within two workdays of the receipt of notice by the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-42; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.03)  
Sec. 66-111. - Type, capacity, location and layout; conditions under which permit prohibited; no discharge to natural outlet. 
The type, capacity, location and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of ADEM and the county health department. No permit shall be issued for any private wastewater disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 15,000 square feet, nor where the property is within 150 feet of an existing public sanitary sewer. No septic tank shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Code 1992, § 13-43; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.04)  
Sec. 66-112. - Termination of use when public sewer becomes available. 
At such time as a public sewer becomes available to property served by a private wastewater disposal system and problems as defined in section 66-80 are determined by the city to exist, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer, as provided in division 2 of this article, within 90 days and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable material. 
(Code 1992, § 13-44; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.05)  
Sec. 66-113. - Maintenance of system. 
The owners shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-45; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.06)  
Sec. 66-114. - Conditions for discharge of tank wastes. 
Holding tank wastes and septic tank wastes from private systems shall be discharged into the sewerage system only under the following conditions: 
(1)  No person owning vacuum pump or septic tank trucks or other liquid waste transport trucks shall discharge directly or indirectly such wastewater into the sewerage system unless such person shall first have applied for and received a wastewater haulers discharge permit from the city. All applicants for wastewater haulers discharge permits shall complete such forms as required by the city, pay appropriate fees and agree in writing to abide by the provisions of this section and any special conditions or regulations established by the city. The owners of such vehicles shall affix and display a permit number on the side of each vehicle used for such purposes. Such permits shall be valid for a maximum period of one year from the date of issuance, provided that such permit shall be subject to revocation by the city for violation of any provision of this division or reasonable regulation established by the city. Such permits shall be limited to the discharge of sanitary sewage containing no industrial waste. Pumpage from commercial grease traps is specifically prohibited from discharge into the sewerage system. The city shall designate the locations and times where such trucks may be discharged and may refuse to accept any truckload of waste at its absolute discretion where it appears that the waste could interfere with the effective operation of the sewerage system. 
(2)  No person shall discharge any other holding tank waste including industrial process wastes into the sewerage system unless such person shall have applied for and have been issued a permit by the city. Unless otherwise allowed under the terms and conditions of the permit, a separate permit shall be secured for each separate discharge. The permit shall state the specific location of discharge, the time of day the discharge is to occur and the volume of the discharge, and shall limit the wastewater constituents and characteristics of the discharge. Such user shall pay any applicable charges or fees therefor, and shall comply with the conditions of the permit issued by the city. 
(3)  The owner of any vehicle for which a wastewater haulers discharge permit is requested, must be a resident of the city, and the business of such owner must be located in the city. The mayor shall have the authority to waive the residency and business location requirements upon written application and appropriate bond and surety as required and approved by the mayor. 
(4)  No person shall operate a dumping station for the discharge of sanitary sewage from recreational vehicles into the sewerage system unless the user of the dumping station has first applied for and received a recreational vehicle dumping station permit from the city. All applicants for recreational vehicle dumping station permits shall complete such forms as required by the city, pay appropriate fees and agree in writing to abide by the provisions of this division and any special conditions or regulations established by the city. These permits shall be issued only for approved facilities designed for and to receive sanitary sewage only. 
(Code 1992, § 13-46; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.07; Ord. of 6-7-1983(1))  
Sec. 66-115. - Additional requirements. 
No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by federal or state agencies. 
(Code 1992, § 13-47; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 3.08)  
Secs. 66-116—66-143. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS, CONNECTIONS AND PERMITS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 66-144. - Separate and independent building sewers. 
A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer for the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. 
(Code 1992, § 13-62; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.14)  
Sec. 66-145. - Use of existing building sewers. 
Existing building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the city to meet all the requirements of this division and other ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-63; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.15)  
Sec. 66-146. - Materials, specifications, etc., of building sewers. 
The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of the city building code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Code 1992, § 13-64; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.16)  
Sec. 66-147. - Building sewer elevation; lift. 
Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 1992, § 13-65; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.17)  
Sec. 66-148. - Connecting building sewer to public sewer; regulations. 
The connection of the building sewer to the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the city building code, other applicable rules and regulations of the city or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city before installation. All connections from a private dwelling or commercial property to public sewer systems, including the installation of all exterior lines and fixtures, must be performed by a licensed plumber. This shall not include repair of existing fixtures but shall include total replacement of existing fixtures. 
(Code 1992, § 13-66; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.18; Ord. of 12-6-1994)  
Sec. 66-149. - Inspection and testing of building sewer. 
The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-67; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.19)  
Sec. 66-150. - Responsibility of owner for cost of building sewer installation and connection. 
All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owners. The owners shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the installation or maintenance of the building sewer. Maintenance after installation of the sewer from the building to the connection pipe, which connection pipe shall be defined as that pipe receiving sewer laterals from more than one building on a public right-of-way or easement, shall be borne by the owners. The owners shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the installation or maintenance of the building sewer. 
(Code 1992, § 13-68; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.13; Ord. No. 95-042, 12-19-1995)  
Sec. 66-151. - Guarding excavations; restoring street surfaces. 
(a)  All excavations for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazards. 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-69; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.20)  
Sec. 66-152. - Conformance to OSHA regulations. 
All construction activities shall conform to all applicable OSHA regulations. 
(Code 1992, § 13-69.1; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.21)  
Secs. 66-153—66-172. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Permits 
 
Sec. 66-173. - Permit required to make connection with sewer. 
No unauthorized persons shall uncover, make any connections with or openings into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-50; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.01)  
Sec. 66-174. - Classes of sewer permits. 
There shall be two classes of sewer permits: 
(1)  Building sewer permits for residential, commercial, industrial or public facilities. 
(2)  State indirect discharge (SID) permits for significant industrial users as defined in section 66-46. 
(Code 1992, § 13-51; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.02)  
Sec. 66-175. - Application for and issuance of permit to connect with city sewers. 
Any person desiring to tap, cut or connect onto the city sanitary sewer line or system shall make application in writing to the director of planning and development setting forth the street and location of the place where such sewer line is to be tapped, cut or connected, the name and address of the owner of the property which is to be connected with such sewer line, and such other information as the director of planning and development shall require. Such application shall be filed in the office of the director of planning and development and upon the payment of fees as required in the following sections, the director of planning and development shall issue a permit authorizing such connection. 
(Code 1992, § 13-52; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.03; Ord. of 10-3-1989)  
Sec. 66-176. - SID permit required. 
In addition to the requirements of section 66-175, any person who proposes to originate the discharge of any industrial waste for the first time into the sewerage system or who proposes to make a significant change in the character or volume of any industrial waste theretofore discharged into the sewerage system, shall make application to ADEM through the city for a SID permit and obtain a permit prior to connecting to the sewerage system or making a significant change in such person's contribution thereto. The applications shall be supplemented by any information that may have been furnished by the applicant to any other governmental agency and by such other plans or other data as the city may reasonably require for purposes of determining whether the qualifications are met as specified in section 66-181. 
(Code 1992, § 13-53; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.04)  
Sec. 66-177. - Definition of significant change. 
A significant change in the character or volume of an industrial waste, for purposes of section 66-176, shall be deemed to be proposed if substances, compounds and elements not previously constituting any part of a user's industrial waste are to be introduced into such waste, or if the average concentration of any substance, compound or element in the waste or average volume proposed to be discharged will cause a violation of any permit limitation. In case of doubt as to whether an intended change constitutes a significant change, it shall be the responsibility of the user intending to make such a change to make the necessary application, or obtain a written ruling from the city and ADEM that an application for a SID permit is not required. 
(Code 1992, § 13-54; Ord. of 2-15-1983(1), § 4.05)  
Sec. 66-178. - Continuation of existing users without SID permits. 
Any user who, on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, was operating within the city and is a SIU from which industrial waste is discharged into the sewerage system, hereinafter called an existing significant industrial user, may continue such discharge until notified by the city in writing that a SID permit will be required and until an application has been submitted to and denied by the city and ADEM in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The city, after consultation with ADEM, shall issue written notices to existing significant industrial users (in such time sequence as it may determine in the light of the staff resources available for the processing of SID permit applications) specifying in each such notice the time within which an existing SIU shall file application for a SID permit. 
(2)  Within the specified time limit, the existing SIU shall file the required application together with any other information as described in section 66-176. 
(3)  An existing SIU may continue to discharge, after complying with the requirement to file an application for a SID permit, unless and until receipt by the applicant of a written notice specifying the reasons for denial of a SID permit and specifying what remedial action, if any, must be taken to qualify the applicant for a permit. 
(Code 1992, § 13-55; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.06)  
Sec. 66-179. - Application for SID permit by user subject to national categorical pretreatment standard. 
Any user subject to a new national categorical pretreatment standard shall apply for a new SID permit within 180 days after the promulgation of the applicable national categorical pretreatment standard. SID permits of users subject to such standards shall be issued or reissued in compliance with such standards within the time frames prescribed by such standards. 
(Code 1992, § 13-56; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.07)  
Sec. 66-180. - Discharge prohibited on denial of SID permit. 
In any case, where a final determination has been made denying a SID permit, it shall be unlawful for any person so denied a SID permit to discharge industrial waste into the sewerage system. 
(Code 1992, § 13-57; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.08)  
Sec. 66-181. - Conditions for issuance or renewal of SID permit. 
A SID permit will be issued or renewed by ADEM only when satisfactory information has been submitted to indicate that: 
(1)  Sewerage system capacity is available for receiving the discharge of industrial waste at the proposed point of discharge. 
(2)  Waste being discharged or proposed to be discharged is amenable to treatment by the processes employed in the wastewater treatment plants of the city and will not impair the ability of the city to comply with water quality standards or effluent standards established by the state or by federal regulatory agencies. 
(3)  Waste being discharged or proposed to be discharged will not cause damage to the sewerage system including the wastewater treatment facilities, will not constitute a hazard to humans or animals and will not be capable of creating a public nuisance. 
(4)  Concentrations of substances, compounds and elements in the waste being discharged or proposed to be discharged do not exceed limits established by the city, state or federal authorities. 
(5)  Where the wastewater contains or may contain any substances, compounds or elements controlled or limited by this article, an adequate program of self-monitoring of flow and wastewater characteristics will be established and maintained by the industry effected by this article to ensure that the discharge meets the requirements of this article and any SID permit conditions. 
(Code 1992, § 13-58; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.09)  
Sec. 66-182. - Contents of SID permit. 
A SID permit shall include all appropriate requirements of this article and all other applicable regulations established by the city and ADEM. SID permits may contain the following: 
(1)  Limits on the average and maximum wastewater constituents, volume and characteristics. The city or ADEM may impose mass limitations on users who are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements or in other cases where the imposition of mass limitations is appropriate. 
(2)  Limits on average and maximum rates and time of discharge or requirements for flow regulations and equalization. 
(3)  Requirements for installation and maintenance of inspection and/or sampling facilities. 
(4)  Specifications for monitoring programs that may include sampling locations, frequency of sampling, number, types and standards for tests and reporting schedules. 
(5)  Compliance schedules. 
(6)  Requirements for submission of technical reports or discharge reports as per sections 66-290 through 66-294. 
(7)  Requirements for maintaining and retaining plant records relating to wastewater discharges as specified by the city and ADEM and affording the city and ADEM access thereto. 
(8)  Requirements for notification of the city and ADEM of any new introduction of wastewater constituents or any substantial changes in the volume or character of the wastewater constituents being introduced into the sewerage system. 
(9)  Requirements for notification of slug discharges in accordance with sections 66-229 through 66-231. 
(10)  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the city or ADEM, to ensure compliance with the requirements and purposes of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 13-59; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.10)  
Sec. 66-183. - SID permit period. 
A SID permit shall be issued for a specified time period not to exceed five years. The user shall apply for SID permit reissuance a minimum of 90 days prior to the expiration of the user's existing SID permit. The terms and conditions of the SID permit may be subject to modification by the city or ADEM during the term of the SID permit as limitations or requirements as identified in division 5 of this article are modified or other just cause exists. The user shall be informed of any proposed changes in the SID permit at least 30 days prior to the effective date of change. Any changes or new conditions in the SID permit shall include a reasonable time schedule for compliance. 
(Code 1992, § 13-60; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.11)  
Sec. 66-184. - SID permit limited to specific user and operation. 
A SID permit is issued to a specified user for a specific operation. A SID permit shall not be reassigned or transferred or sold to a new owner, new user, different premises or a new or changed operation without prior submission of applicable revisions to the application for the existing SID permit and without the approval of the city and ADEM. Any succeeding owner or user shall also comply with the terms and conditions of the existing SID permit. 
(Code 1992, § 13-61; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 4.12)  
Secs. 66-185—66-206. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PROHIBITED DISCHARGES 
 
Sec. 66-207. - General prohibition. 
No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the sewerage system. These general prohibitions apply to all such users of the sewerage system whether or not the user is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements. 
(Code 1992, § 13-70; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 5.01)  
Sec. 66-208. - Enumeration of wastes prohibited generally under certain conditions. 
No user shall discharge or deposit any of the following materials, waste materials, wastes, gases or liquids into any sewer forming part of the sewerage system except where these may constitute occasional, intermittent inclusions in the wastewaters discharged from residential premises: 
(1)  Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the wastewater treatment plant or resulting in other interference with the treatment processes but, in no case, wastewater with a temperature which exceeds 60 degrees Celsius (140 degrees Fahrenheit) at its introduction into the sewerage system or which exceeds 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) at its introduction into a wastewater treatment plant. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing more than 50 mg/l of fat, oil or grease or other substances that will solidify or become viscous at temperatures between zero degrees Celsius (32 degrees Fahrenheit) and 60 degrees Celsius (140 degrees Fahrenheit). 
(3)  Wastewater from industrial users containing floatable oils, fat or grease. 
(4)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded so that no particles are any greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
(5)  Any wastes capable of causing abnormal corrosion, abnormal deterioration, damage to or creating a hazard to structures or equipment of the sewerage system or to humans or animals or interfering with proper operation of the city's wastewater treatment plants. All wastes discharged to the sewerage system must have a pH value in the range of six to ten standard units. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, concentrated acids or alkalis and high concentrations of compounds of sulfur, chlorine and fluorine and substances which may react with water to form strongly acidic or basic products. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes having a color which is not removable by existing wastewater treatment processes and which causes plant effluent to exceed color requirements for discharge to the receiving waters. 
(Code 1992, § 13-71; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 5.02)  
Sec. 66-209. - Enumeration of wastes prohibited absolutely. 
No user shall discharge or deposit any of the following materials, waste materials, waste gases or liquids into any sewer forming a part of the sewerage system: 
(1)  Any liquids, solids or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are or may be sufficient, either alone or by interaction with other substances, to cause fire or explosion or be injurious to any other way to the sewerage system or to the operation of the system. At no time shall two successive readings (15 to 30 minutes between readings) on an explosion hazard meter (model GX-3 as manufactured by Gas Tech, Inc., Mountain View, California, references to establish a standard of quality for a measuring device) at the point of discharge into the sewerage system be more than five percent, nor any single reading over ten percent, of the lower explosive limit (L.E.L.) of the meter. Prohibited materials covered by this section include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, fuel oil, motor oil, mineral spirits, commercial solvents, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides and hydrides. 
(2)  Any other solid or viscous substance in quantity or character capable of causing obstruction to flow in sewers or interference with proper operation of wastewater treatment facilities such as, but not limited to, eggshells from egg processors, ashes, cinders, ceramic wastes, sand, mud, straw, shavings, thread, glass, rags, metal, feathers, bones, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, insulation materials, fibers of any kind, stock or poultry feeds, processed grains, viscera or other fleshy particles from processing or packing plants or lime or similar sludges. 
(3)  Any noxious or malodorous solids, liquids or gases, which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life or are or may be sufficient to prevent entry into a sewer for its maintenance and repair. 
(4)  Any substance which may cause wastewater treatment plant effluent or any other product of the sewerage system such as residue, sludge or scum to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process. In no case shall a substance discharged to the sewerage system cause the system to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed by local, state or federal authorities. 
(5)  Any substance that will cause the sewerage system to violate its NPDES permit and/or the quality standards of the receiving stream. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes which, by interaction with other waters or wastes in the sewerage system, releases obnoxious gases, forms suspended solids which interfere with the sewerage system or creates a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
(7)  Any form of inflow as defined by section 66-46, including storm drainage and uncontaminated thermal process water. 
(8)  Infiltration as defined by section 66-46 in excess of 200 gallons per inch of pipe diameter per mile of pipe per day. 
(9)  Any unpolluted wastewater, as defined in section 66-46. 
(Code 1992, § 13-72; Ord. of 3-15-1983(1), § 5.03)  
Sec. 66-210. - Prohibited wastes above certain limits. 
(a)  No user shall discharge into any sewer forming part of the sewerage system any of the following materials in concentrations exceeding the stated limits: 
(1)  Any waters or wastes that contain more than ten mg/l of hydrogen sulphide, sulphur dioxide or nitrous oxide. 
(2)  Any toxic or poisonous substance or any other materials in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with the wastewater treatment processes or to constitute a hazard to humans or animals or to cause a violation of the water quality standards or effluent standards for the stream or watercourse receiving the effluent from a wastewater treatment plant or to exceed limitations set forth in categorical pretreatment standards. 
(3)  Any waters containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual provisions, attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the wastewater treatment plants. 
(4)  Any waters containing quantities of radium or naturally occurring or artificially produced radioisotopes in excess of presently existing or subsequently accepted limits for drinking water as established by current drinking water regulations promulgated by EPA. 
(5)  Any wastewater containing in excess of: 
FIXED UPPER LIMITS FOR CONSTITUENTS
