MINIMUM LOT SIZE: It is the intent of the ordinance that the lots of sufficient size be used for any industrial service or business use to provide adequate parking and loading space in addition to the space required for the other normal operations of the enterprise. 
MINIMUM YARD SIZE: Front Yard: None specified, except where existing establishments (other than residential) are set back, any new structure shall be set back not less than the average of the setbacks of the existing establishments within one hundred (100) feet each side thereof. Side Yards: None specified, except a lot adjoining along its side lot line another lot which is in a residential district, there shall be a side yard not less than eight (8) feed wide. Rear Yard: None specified. 
MAXIMUM HEIGHT: 50 feet or 4 stories. 
OFF-STREET PARKING: Space necessary to store accommodate the cars of all workers in the industry or use. Also, space necessary to store overnight all vehicles incidental to the operation of the industry or use. 
OFF-STREET LOADING AND UNLOADING: Shall provide adequate space for loading or unloading all vehicles or trucks incidental to the operation of the industry or use. 

M-2 
(General Industry) 	USES PERMITTED: Any industrial, service or commercial use, except those which in the opinion of the Building Inspector would cause noise, smoke, gas, vibration, fumes, dust, or other objectionable conditions, which would affect a considerable portion of the city. 
USES PERMITTED ON APPEAL: Any industrial, service or commercial use, and subject to such conditions and safeguards as the Board of Zoning Adjustment may require to preserve and protect any portions of the city which otherwise could be adversely affected. 
TEMPORARY STRUCTURE: Where such structures shall be used for a period of not to exceed 18 months prior to construction of a permanent structure, which will replace the temporary structure. The owner must give evidence, satisfactory to the Board of Zoning Adjustment, of such owner's good faith and intent to construct or have constructed, a permanent structure. Under no circumstances shall such structures be authorized as a residence or habitation. 
USES PROHIBITED: Residences and apartments, excepting quarters for a watchman or custodian and his family. 	MINIMUM LOT SIZE: Same as for M-1 Indus trial District. 
MINIMUM YARD SIZE: None specified. 
MAXIMUM HEIGHT: 50 feet or 4 stories. 
OFF-STREET LOADING AND UN LOADING: Same as for M-1 Industrial District.

No accessory structure shall exceed two (2) stories or twenty-five (25) feet in height.

ARTICLE 8. - MOBILE HOME SUBDIVISIONS 
 
Section 81. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this ordinance is to provide minimum standards to assure the orderly and beneficial development of mobile home subdivisions, parks and parking areas, without interrupting existing development patterns and becoming a detriment to the surrounding area from an aesthetic, topographical, or incompatible point of view. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 81)  
Section 82. - Definitions. 
(82.1)  [ Mobile home or trailer. ] "Mobile home" or "trailer" is one that is fully equipped for single family living including a kitchen, a toilet and a bath or shower. 
(82.2)  Dependent trailer. The term "dependent trailer" is a trailer that does not have a toilet and a bath or shower. 
(82.3)  Mobile homes subdivision. The term "mobile homes subdivision" shall be construed to mean a subdivision in which the lot is individually owned, usually by its occupant, subject to the terms of this ordinance. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 82)  
Section 83. - Use. 
(83.1)  No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, altered, or enlarged in T-1, T-2 or T-3 districts except for the following uses and in conformance with Article 7 "District Requirements": 
(83.1-1)  Mobile home subdivision, parks and parking areas. 
(83.1-2)  Accessory structure as defined in section 68.1, Article 6 of this ordinance. 
(83.1-3)  Dependent trailers are specifically excluded. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 83)  
Section 84. - Requirements for a mobile home subdivision or parking area. 
(84.1)  Water, sewage, garbage and trash disposal shall meet or exceed the standards set forth by the City of Prattville. 
(84.2)  All electric installations shall comply with or exceed minimum standards as set by the City of Prattville. 
(84.3)  All streets and public driveways within subdivisions or parks shall be lighted at night with electric lamps according to plans recommended and approved by the City of Prattville. 
(84.4)  There shall be set aside a recreational area or areas within subdivisions or parks which shall be suitably restricted to such use. The size of the recreational area shall be compatible with the size of the subdivision and shall be subject to the approval of the City of Prattville Planning Commission. 
(84.5)  A green belt strip or other suitable type of buffer may be required by the City Planning Commission if the location of the subdivision is such that a buffer strip would be desirable. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 84)  
Section 85. - Space requirements (individual). 
(85.1)  Each mobile home space shall be improved with one (1) patio of concrete or other suitable impervious material, having a minimum area of one hundred fifty (150) square feet, and one (1) gravel or better home-pad of size equal to or greater than the dimensions of the trailer located on the pad, but in no case less than ten (10) feet by forty (40) feet. 
(85.2)  Additions to mobile homes shall be limited to pre-manufactured verandas, carports, and patio covers similar in appearance and design to such mobile home. Exceptions: Conventional roof structures of sound structural and architectural design constructed in accordance with the Standard Building Code may be added. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 85)  
Section 86. - Construction. 
No mobile home subdivision, park or parking area shall be permitted in the City of Prattville or within its police jurisdiction except upon recommendation and approval of the City Planning Commission. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 86)  
Section 87. - Application for zoning. 
Application to the City Planning Commission for the use of land as a mobile home subdivision or park shall be accompanied by a development plan that complies with the requirements of this ordinance and all subdivision regulations. 
The initial application shall be in writing[,] signed by the applicant, and shall include the following: 
(a)  Location and legal description of area, indicating use of surrounding areas. 
(b)  Detailed map of area with dimensions, contours on two-foot intervals and area drainage. 
(c)  Detailed plans showing arrangements of access streets and connection with traffic artery, lot layout, recreation areas and facilities, buffer zone, and proposed green belt planting. 
(d)  Detailed plans for the proposed sewage, drainage, street paving and such other information as may be required by the City of Prattville. 
(e)  Plans and specifications of all buildings, improvements and facilities to be constructed within the mobile home subdivision or park. 
(f)  The application and all accompanying plans and documents shall be filed in triplicate. 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 87)  
Section 88. - Fire protection. 
The mobile home area shall be subject to fire regulations of the City of Prattville. 
(88.1)  Conflict with other regulations. Whenever the regulations of the ordinance require or impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other statute or ordinance, the requirements of the ordinance shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other statute or ordinance require more restrictive standards than are required by this ordinance, the provisions of such statute or ordinance shall govern. 
(88.2)  Separability of provisions. Should any section or provision of this ordinance be declared invalid, such decisions shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. 
(88.3)  Adoption. This ordinance shall be effective on and after the eighteenth day of April 1978. 
(88.4)  Permits. No person shall park or place a mobile home on any lot within a subdivision or park without first obtaining a permit from the city. The minimum fee for such permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. of 10-21-1969; Ord. of 4-18-1978, § 88)  
ARTICLE 9. - TOWNHOUSES 
 
Section 91. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to permit within the City of Prattville the construction of townhouses only upon application and on approval of a detailed site plan within an area of suitable location and character for such development as determined by existing land use characteristics, and future land use as defined in the Prattville land use plan. It is the further purpose and intent that the allowance of the construction of townhouses within the City of Prattville be in keeping with this purpose, and will provide present and future residents of the City of Prattville increased alternate housing opportunities and promote the more effective, efficient and economical utilization of current land resources, thereby benefiting the general public. 
(Ord. of 3-16-1976)  
Section 92. - General requirements. 
(92.1)  Not more than ten (10) contiguous townhouses shall be built in a row along the same front line, and not more than twenty (20) townhouses shall be contiguous. 
(92.2)  Contiguous townhouses shall be separated by an appropriate fire wall built into [in] conformance with specifications provided by the Standard Building Code and the Standard Fire Prevention Code. 
(92.3)  Each townhouse unit shall be constructed on its own lot. Townhouses constructed in a condominium development shall be exempt from this requirement only by approval of the Planning Commission. 
(92.4)  No side yard shall be required except at the unattached end of the townhouse complex, in which case the minimum width shall be ten (10) feet. 
(92.5)  The minimum depth of the front yard shall be twenty (20) feet. 
(92.6)  No townhouse unit shall extend more than five (5) feet in front of a building located on an adjoining lot of dissimilar use. 
(92.7)  No portion of a townhouse or accessory structure in, or related to, one (1) townhouse complex, shall be closer than twenty (20) feet to any portion of any townhouse or accessory structure, related to another townhouse complex structure, or to any building outside the townhouse area. 
(92.8)  Each townhouse unit shall have its own yard, containing not less than two hundred (200) square feet, reasonably secluded from view from the streets or from the neighboring property. 
(92.9)  There shall be provided two (2) off-street parking spaces for each townhouse unit. Unless a specific waiver is granted by the Planning Commission, all off-street parking facilities shall be grouped in bays, whether adjacent to streets or in interior blocks. No off-street parking spaces shall be more than one hundred fifty (150) feet by the most direct pedestrian route from the door of the dwelling unit, to which such parking belongs. 
(92.10)  The following is the minimum required area, width and height for each townhouse unit: 
Minimum lot area. One-family townhouse: two thousand (2,000) square feet. 
Minimum lot width at building line: twenty (20) feet. 
Minimum depth at front yard: twenty (20) feet. 
Minimum depth at rear yard: twenty (20) feet. 
Minimum width of one (1) side yard: ten (10) feet. 
(At unattached end of townhouse complex). 
Maximum building height: thirty-five (35) feet. 
Maximum number of stories: two and one-half (2½). 
Off-street parking requirement: two (2) car spaces per family dwelling unit. 
(Ord. of 3-16-1976)  
Section 93. - Site requirements. 
Prior to the approval of the construction of a townhouse area, a detailed site plan must be submitted [to] and approved by the Prattville Planning Commission. Such site plan shall meet all the requirements specified in the Prattville Subdivision Regulations for a preliminary plat review, as provided under the experimental subdivision section of the Prattville Subdivision Regulations. The Planning Commission may waive or modify the standards or requirements of the Prattville Subdivision Regulations if the Commission finds the experimental subdivision provides adequate public space and improvement for circulation, recreation, light, air, service needs of the tract of land when fully developed and populated, and also provides such covenants and other legal provisions as will assure conformity to the achievement of the plan. 
(Ord. of 3-16-1976)  
Section 94. - Construction. 
No townhouse within the City of Prattville shall be constructed nor construction commenced until all the requirements of this article have been met and final approval given as required by the City of Prattville. 
(Ord. of 3-16-1976)  
Section 95. - Conflict with other regulations. 
Whenever the regulations of this article require or impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other statute or ordinance, the requirements of this article shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other statute or ordinance require more restrictive standards than are required by this article, the provisions of such statute or ordinance shall govern. 
(Ord. of 3-16-1976)  
Section 96. - Acceptability of provisions. 
Should any section or provision of this article be declared invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(Ord. of 3-16-1976)  
ARTICLE 10. - PATIO GARDEN HOMES 
 
Section 101. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to permit within the City of Prattville the construction of patio garden homes only upon application of a detailed site plan within an area of suitable location and character for such development as determined by existing land use characteristics, and future land use as defined in the Prattville land use plan. It is the further purpose and intent that the allowance of the construction of patio garden homes within the City of Prattville be in keeping with this purpose, and will provide present and future residents of the City of Prattville increased alternate housing opportunities and promote the more effective, efficient and economical utilization of current land resources, thereby benefiting the general public. It is the further purpose that patio garden homes may be appropriately intermingled with other types of housing, shall constitute groupings making efficient, economical, comfortable, and convenient use of land and open space; and shall serve the public purpose of zoning by means alternative to conventional arrangements of yards and building areas. 
(Ord. of 12-9-1986, § 101; Ord. No. 2001-016, § 101, 7-10-2001)  
Section 102. - General requirements. 
(102.1) Not more than two (2) contiguous patio garden homes shall be connected. 
(102.2) Each patio home shall be constructed on its own lot, and shall be a minimum of forty (40) feet at the building line, minimum lot area shall be four thousand 4,000 square feet. 
(102.3) Each patio home lot shall have one (1) side yard with a minimum depth of five (5) feet. Minimum depth of front yards shall be twenty (20) feet. Minimum depth of rear yards shall be fifteen (15) feet. Fireplace and chimney may be placed in the rear yard setback provided they do not project beyond the thirty-inch permitted roof overhang and provided they do not restrict or obstruct any drainage easement, whether existing or proposed. 
(102.4) The required side yards must be kept perpetually free of permanent obstructions, accessory structures, walls and fences without gates. 
(102.5) Privacy fences or walls may be placed on or along any lot lines provided that such fences or walls are not constructed in such a manner as to block any local lot drainage and provided gates or other openings are provided that will not restrict access for fire protection. An eight-foot-maximum height limit will be permitted for privacy fences or walls located on or along any required side or rear yard. 
(102.6) Each patio garden home shall have on its own lot one (1) yard containing not less than six hundred (600) square feet, reasonably secluded from view of streets or neighboring property. 
(102.7) Maximum lot coverage permitted for the main dwelling shall be one hundred (100) percent of permitted building area not including coverage permitted for accessory buildings or structures. 
(102.8) Off-street parking shall be provided at the rate of two (2) spaces per dwelling unit and shall be located within the interior of the lot. Garages shall not be credited toward the parking requirements, if said garage is a part of the main dwelling or attached to the main dwelling. 
(102.9) The exterior wall of the patio garden home, or any accessory structures on the zero-foot side yard setback shall not project over the property line. Roof overhang may penetrate maintenance and drainage easement of the adjacent lot a maximum of thirty (30) inches, provided the roof shall be so designed that water runoff shall be restricted to the drainage easement area. 
(102.10) The number of windows, doors or other openings allowed on walls fronting the sidelines shall be governed by the Table 600 of the Southern Building Code (or governed by the adopted building code currently enforced by the City of Prattville or by the most restrictive code.) Where adjacent zero lot line dwellings are not constructed against or along a common lot line, a perpetual wall maintenance easement of three (3) feet in width along and parallel to the adjacent lot shall be provided. 
(102.11) Where adjacent zero lot line dwellings are not constructed against or along a common lot line, a perpetual drainage easement shall be provided, which shall be approved by the Planning Commission. Fences and walls may be located on or along this easement provided gates or other openings that will not block local lot drainage are maintained. A "hold harmless agreement" shall be required. 
(102.12) The lot adjacent to the zero setback side yard must be under the same ownership at the time of initial construction (ensuring that a developer does not infringe on the property rights of adjacent tracts) or a ten-foot side setback shall be required, provided the adjacent property is not zoned for patio garden homes or is not a permitted use in the adjacent zoning district. 
(102.13) No accessory structures shall be erected in a required front, side, street side yard, or open space. Accessory structures shall be permitted in the rear yard and shall not exceed one and one-half (1½) stories in height and shall not cover more than twenty-five (25) percent of the required rear yard, and shall be permitted a zero-foot setback from the rear yard and side property lines and five (5) feet from any other structure on the same lot. 
(102.14) Unattached garages and carports shall be permitted in addition to the twenty-five-percent coverage for accessory structures, but shall not exceed six hundred (600) square feet in area; and shall not be placed in any required front, side, or street side yard or open space; and shall not exceed one and one-half (1½) stories in height; and shall be permitted a zero setback from the rear and side property lines, and five (5) feet from any other structure on the same lot. 
(Ord. of 12-9-1986, § 102; Ord. No. 2001-016, § 102, 7-10-2001)  
Section 103. - Site requirements. 
Prior to the approval of the construction of a patio garden home area, detailed site plan must be submitted and approved by the Prattville Planning Commission. Such site plan shall meet all the requirements specified in the Prattville subdivision regulations for a preliminary plat review, as provided under the experimental subdivision section of the Prattville subdivision regulations. The Planning Commission may waive or modify the standards and requirements of the Prattville subdivision regulations if the Commission finds the experimental subdivision provides adequate public space and improvements for circulation, recreation, light, air, service needs of the tract of land when fully developed and populated, and also provides such covenants and other legal provisions as will assure conformity to the achievement of the plan. 
(Ord. of 12-9-1986, § 103)  
Section 104. - Construction. 
No patio garden home within the City of Prattville shall be constructed, nor construction commenced, until all the requirements of this article have been met and final approval given as required by the City of Prattville. 
(Ord. of 12-9-1986, § 104)  
Section 105. - Conflict with other regulations. 
Whenever the regulations of this article require or impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other statute or ordinance, the requirements of this article shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other statute or ordinance require more restrictive standards than are required by this article, the provisions of such statute or ordinance shall govern. 
(Ord. of 12-9-1986, § 105)  
ARTICLE 11. - PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— The ordinance comprising this article labeled it "Section 10," whereas there already existed Article 10. The editor has redesignated it Article 11, and numbered the sections accordingly. 
 
Section 111. - Purpose. 
The Planned Unit Development (PUD) District is intended to provide flexible land use regulations by using a review and approval process to impose a mixture of standards from other zoning districts or to negotiate specific performance criteria. The overall character of the PUD District shall be compatible to surrounding neighborhoods and preserve valuable natural features while permitting greater variety in the type of design, siting of structures, and combination of uses. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 1)  
Section 112. - Community objectives. 
PUD Districts shall be reviewed in terms of addressing the following general objectives and specific standards set forth in subsequent sections of this ordinance: 
1.  Promotes choice in housing type, lot size or neighborhood environment available to residents. 
2.  Preserves trees, slopes, geological features or prevents adverse effects such as erosion. 
3.  Attains more efficient use of land resulting in smaller utility networks. 
4.  Achieves a development pattern in harmony with the comprehensive plan with a more desirable environment than would be achieved through the strict application of zoning and subdivision requirements. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 2)  
Section 113. - Planned unit development (PUD) district application, review and approval procedure. 
Whenever a PUD District is proposed, before any subdivision site improvements are made or building permits are issued, the developer, or his agent, shall apply for and secure approval for a PUD District in accordance with the following procedures: 
1.  Sketch plan. In order to allow the City Council, City Planning Commission and the developer to understand and agree on the project and specific design requirements prior to detailed design, the developer shall (mandatory) submit a sketch plan to the City Planning Commission at least fourteen (14) days before the meeting at which it is to be considered. 
2.  Staff review. The staff of the Prattville Planning and Engineering Department shall review and coordinate reviews by other departments and utilities prior to consideration of the proposed [proposal] by the Planning Commission. Staff comments shall be made for the benefit and aid of the Planning Commission. 
3.  Planning Commission review and recommendations to Council. The Planning Commission shall review the proposed planned unit development and take one (1) of the following actions: 
A.  Request the developer to provide additional information and reconsider the proposal at the next regular meeting or at a future regular meeting when the developer can present the data requested. After three (3) requests for data by the Planning Commission, the developer may request the project to be referred to Council. 
B.  Refer the proposal to the City Council with a statement either: 
(1)  Recommending rezoning to PUD. A favorable recommendation shall include a report to the City Council that the applicant may proceed with initiation of the rezoning request and preparation of a preliminary plan. The recommendation shall be based on the following findings, which shall be included as a part of the report: 
(a)  The proposal conforms to the comprehensive plan. 
(b)  The proposal meets the intent, objectives and general requirements of the Planned Unit Development District. 
(c)  The proposal is conceptually sound in that it meets a community need and conforms to accepted design principles in the proposed functional roadway system, land use configuration, open space system, and drainage and utility systems. 
(d)  There are adequate services and utilities available in the construction of the development. 
(2)  A conditional recommendation stating objections to the sketch plan and may include an alternate proposal by the Planning Commission for the zoning of the area under consideration. 
(3)  Opposing the rezoning and stating the reasons for opposition. 
4.  Council action. Upon receipt of a PUD proposal and the Planning Commission's review statement, the Council shall schedule a public hearing and publish notices in accordance with the provisions of the Prattville Zoning Ordinance. The Council shall conduct the public hearing and consider the PUD rezoning at the following Council meeting. 
A.  If the Council refuses the PUD zoning, the appeal process applicable to zoning shall be followed. 
B.  If the PUD zoning is granted, it shall become effective upon modification and publication as provided by law and be considered to be valid for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days during which time preliminary plans shall be filed with the Planning Commission. 
Failure to file a preliminary plan shall be cause to consider the project as inactive and the zoning shall revert to the districts applicable prior to the PUD. 
5.  Planning Commission review of preliminary plan. 
A.  After receiving rezoning from the City Council on a sketch plan, the applicant may prepare a preliminary site plan to submit to the City Planning Commission for approval. The preliminary plan shall conform to the sketch plan that has received preliminary approval and was the basis for rezoning. It should incorporate any revisions or other features that may have been required by the City Council. All such compliances shall be clearly indicated by the applicant on the appropriate submission. 
B.  The developer shall submit the preliminary plan to the City Planning Commission at least fourteen (14) days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. The Planning Commission shall conduct a public hearing on the proposal in conformance with the procedures and notice requirements normally used for subdivision proposals. 
At least five (5) days before the meeting and public hearing, the Department of Planning and Engineering shall notify all adjacent property owners of the hearing by mail. After the Planning Commission conducts the public hearing and reviews the preliminary plan, it may: 
(1)  Request additional information and reconsider the proposal at a later meeting. 
(2)  Grant conditional approval and specify additional changes or design features, which would make the project acceptable. Such conditions shall be consistent with the conditional approval provisions of the zoning ordinance or subdivision regulations. 
(3)  Disapprove the proposal. If disapproved by the Planning Commission, the appeal process applicable to subdivision regulations shall be followed. 
(4)  Approve the proposal. The effect of approval shall be similar to the preliminary plan approval in the subdivision regulations and enable the developer to begin site work or post surety for construction of public facilities. 
C.  The City Planning Commission's review of the preliminary site plan shall consider the following factors. 
(1)  Adequacy and arrangement of vehicular traffic access and circulation, including intersections, road widths, channelization, traffic controls, and pedestrian movement. 
(2)  Location, arrangement, appearance, and sufficiency of off-street parking. 
(3)  Location, arrangement, size and design of buildings, and lighting. 
(4)  Relationship of the various uses to one another. 
(5)  Adequacy, type and arrangement of trees, shrubs, and other landscaping constituting a visual and/or a noise deterring buffer between adjacent used [uses] and adjoining lands. 
(6)  In the case of multiple dwellings, the adequacy of usable open space for playgrounds and recreation. 
(7)  Adequacy of storm water and sanitary waste disposal facilities. 
(8)  Adequacy of structures, roadways, and landscaping in areas with moderate to high susceptibility to flooding, ponding and/or erosion. 
(9)  Compliance with all other regulations and the intent of this ordinance. 
D.  Within thirty (30) days of the meeting of which the preliminary plan is submitted, the City Planning Commission shall schedule the public hearing. If no hearing is scheduled within said thirty-day period, the preliminary site plan shall be considered approved. The Planning Commission shall reach a decision on the plan within thirty (30) days after the public hearing. Failure to do so shall also be deemed as approval of the preliminary plan. Notification to the applicant regarding the decision may be in the form of a written statement or by providing a copy of the appropriate section of the minutes. 
6.  Final site plan approval. After installation, inspection and approval of facilities or the posting surety for their construction, the developer may file for final site plan approval. This application shall be filed with the Planning Commission ten (10) days in advance of the meeting at which it is to be considered. The review process and required certificates of approval shall be as set forth in the subdivision regulations. 
7.  Fees. All PUD proposals shall be subject to all fees established in the Prattville Zoning Ordinance and subdivision regulations. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 3)  
Section 114. - General requirements for PUD district. 
1.  Minimum area. The minimum land area required to qualify for PUD District consideration shall be ten (10) acres of contiguous land. 
2.  Ownership. The tract of land for a project must be either in one (1) ownership or the subject of a jointly filed application by the owners of all the properties included. In the case of multiple ownership, the approved site and development shall be binding on all owners. If submitted by someone other than the current owner of the property, the submission must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of the existence of an option to purchase or other agreement so as to insure that the owner is in agreement with the proposed development. 
3.  Location. The PUD District may be applied to any area within the zoning jurisdiction of Prattville where the applicant can demonstrate that the proposed project meets community objectives, specified requirements and self-imposes sufficient criteria so as to be acceptable to City Council and Planning Commission. 
4.  Conformity to comprehensive plan and other regulations. The PUD District shall conform to the general intent of the comprehensive plan and other development regulations of the City of Prattville. During the course of reviewing the various site plans, the Planning Commission may modify regulations in accordance with applicable provisions of the subdivision regulations, but all other codes of the City of Prattville shall remain in full force and effect. Special requirements imposed by the Planning Commission shall also apply and be noted on the final plat. 
5.  Common property in the PUD District. Common property in the PUD District consists of a parcel or parcels of land, together with the improvements thereon, where the use and enjoyment of which are to be shared by the owners and occupants of the planned residential development. When common property exists, the ownership of such common property may be either public or private. 
A.  When common property exists in private ownership, satisfactory arrangements must be made for the improvement, operation, and maintenance of such common property and facilities, including private streets, drives, service and parking areas, and areas for recreation or open space. 
B.  When common property is to become public property, it shall be dedicated to the city in accordance with the provisions of the subdivision regulations of the City of Prattville. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 4)  
Section 115. - Design criteria. 
1.  Uses. The following uses shall qualify for inclusion in the PUD District. The uses permitted in a particular PUD District shall be those uses shown upon the sketch plan approved by the City Council at the time of granting PUD zoning or as modified in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance. 
A.  Residences may be of a variety of types, including one-family, two-family, and multiple-family, but not including mobile homes. This may include units for owners and renters. In developing a balanced community, the user of a variety of housing types shall be deemed desirable in keeping with the objectives of this district. 
B.  Customary accessory or associated uses, such as private garages, storage spaces, recreational and community activities, churches, and schools shall be permitted as appropriate to support the residential development of the district. 
C.  Commercial uses of the family shopping or convenience type such as those specified as permitted uses in the B-1 zone providing the maximum commercial area does not exceed one (1) acre per one hundred (100) dwelling units and site design stipulations as specified by the Planning Commission are met. 
D.  All industrial and other commercial activities are prohibited and where a PUD District abuts such uses, adequate screening or buffer space shall be provided. 
2.  Density. The City Planning Commission shall determine during preliminary plan review the appropriate land use pattern and dwelling unit density for individual projects. These determinations shall be made in accordance with the following guidelines: 
A.  When prototype development plans are not submitted to determine design requirements, detached homes, duplexes, townhouses, apartments and commercial areas shall be developed in accordance with the design standards and density criteria for such uses as [if] they were being developed under individual district regulations. 
B.  When prototype development plans are submitted, the design criteria shall be negotiated and set by the Planning Commission as a part of the site plan review process. 
3.  Other design standards. All buildings shall have a maximum height of thirty-five (35) feet or two and one-half (2½) stories. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 5)  
Section 116. - Sketch plan requirements. 
The sketch plan drawings shall be approximately to scale[,] although they need not be precision finished engineering plans. The submission shall include the following: 
1.  Vicinity map showing the location of the proposed project. 
2.  Site map showing the project property boundaries, proposed internal and existing external land uses and ownership of abutting property. 
3.  Existing site conditions map: 
A.  Identification of the name, plat book, and page number of any recorded subdivision comprising all or part of the site. 
B.  Identification and location of any existing easements, watercourses, lakes, or other significant natural features upon the site. 
C.  Approximate topography of the site. 
4.  Development plan(s) showing the total project and including: 
A.  The interior roadway system, whether public or private, showing the relation to exterior streets which shall be identified by name and existing right-of-way noted. 
B.  A general drainage plan and preliminary utilities layout showing points of connections to existing utilities such as water and sewer and line sizes of existing services. 
C.  Interior open space plan showing public sites and common areas to remain in private ownership. 
D.  A proposed use plan(s) showing the location of proposed uses with the area stated in acres and designating: 
(1)  Type and number of structures to be built by area (i.e., single family, apartments, townhouses) and the size of units. 
(2)  Density of each area calculated in net acres. 
(3)  Prototype development plans and schedule to show yard sizes, setbacks for primary and accessory buildings, typical structure arrangements, individual access and parking provisions. 
E.  If the development is to be staged, a general indication of how the staging is to proceed. 
5.  Narrative statements or documents to describe the following: 
A.  A general description of the character of the area(s) adjoining the project. 
B.  Evidence that the proposal is compatible with the comprehensive plan. 
C.  A general description of community facilities to be provided, such as school sites or recreation facilities or statements on which existing facilities will be used by the proposed residents of the project. This shall include an assessment of the impact on services such as police and fire. 
D.  A general statement regarding how facilities are to be owned and maintained or dedicated to the city. 
E.  Proposed restrictive covenants. 
F.  The proposed method of financing. 
6.  Additional information may be requested by the Planning Commission or City Council as they [it] deem[s] appropriate to fully understand the proposed project. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 6)  
Section 117. - Preliminary plan requirements. 
The preliminary plan submission shall include the following: 
1.  Total project plans and conditions: 
A.  The property boundaries, including metes and bounds. 
B.  An area map showing the applicant's entire holding and all properties, subdivisions, streets, and easements within three hundred (300) feet of applicant's property. 
C.  If slopes exceed three (3) percent, or portions of the site have a moderate to high susceptibility to erosion, or a moderate to high susceptibility of flooding and ponding, a topographic map showing contour intervals of not more than two (2) feet of elevation shall be provided along with an overlay outlining the above susceptible soil. 
D.  Staging plan showing areas already developed, areas for which development approval is being requested, and areas for future development with approximate time table for completion. 
2.  Development site plan. A detailed plan for the project area(s) to be developed showing: 
A.  All information required for preliminary plans as required in the subdivision regulations. 
B.  A site plan showing location, proposed use, and size of all buildings, location of all parking areas, with access and egress drives thereto, location of outdoor storage, if any, including drains, culverts, retaining walls and fences; description of method of sewage disposal and location of such facilities; location and size of all signs; location and proposed development of buffer areas; location and design of lighting facilities; and the amount of building area proposed for nonresidential uses, if any. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 7)  
Section 118. - Final site plan approval. 
A final site plan shall be submitted for approval and include the following: 
A.  All information and certificates as required for final plats in the subdivision regulations. 
(Ord. of 7-21-1981, § 8)  
ARTICLE 12. - SIGNS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— The editor has renumbered the sections in Article 12 to conform with the style of Appendix A. 
 
Section 121. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, certain words and terms are defined as follows: 
Administrator: The Director or Acting Director of the Prattville Planning and Development Department or other person designed [designated] to act as Administrator of this article. 
Setback: Unless otherwise stated, shall mean the minimum distance that any portion of any sign must be set back from the edge of pavement or curb of any public street or road. 
Sign: Any presentation or representation by letter, symbol, number, or combination thereof which is visible from a public right-of-way for the purpose of making something known. 
(1)  Sign categories : 
a.  Business sign: A sign which directs attention to a business, profession, commodity, service or entertainment sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located or to which it is attached. 
b.  Construction sign: A temporary sign identifying builders, artisans, or mechanics at a site of active construction. 
c.  Directional sign: A sign directing traffic to any public or semi-public facility or use including, but not limited to, schools, parks, churches, airports, shopping or industrial centers, or other public or semi-public uses. 
d.  Home occupation [sign]: A sign advertising a home occupation, as defined in the Prattville Zoning Ordinance, and located upon the same premises or lot of the dwelling unit containing the home occupation. 
e.  Identification sign: A permanent sign announcing the name of a subdivision, manufacturer, mobile home park, group housing project, church, school, park, shopping center, apartment complex, industrial center, or public or semi-public use. Such signs may also include space for public advertisements, and the names or [of] proprietor[s], ministers, managers, etc. 
f.  Off-site sign: Any sign not otherwise defined in this section and not located upon the same premises where any advertised business, commodity, activity, service, or product is conducted, sold, offered, or located. 
g.  Public event sign: A sign of a temporary type announcing or giving direction to a public event sponsored by a civic, fraternal, or not-for-profit organization or public agency for the benefit of any civic or charitable cause. 
h.  Political sign: A sign of any political party or announcing the candidacy of any individual for any nomination or expressing a position on any issue subject to a public or party election. 
i.  Real estate sign: A sign advertising the availability of property for sale or lease or the completion of such sale or lease, which is located on the property advertised. 
(2)  Sign structure: The supports, uprights, bracing, or framework of any structure, be it singled-faced [single-faced], doubled-faced [double-faced], V-type, or otherwise exhibiting a sign. 
(3)  Sign types: 
a.  Attached sign: Any sign attached to the wall, roof, facade, canopy, marquee, porch of any structure. This definition shall not include signs painted directly on a building. 
b.  Freestanding sign: A sign supported by its own structure, which support structure is mounted upon the ground and not attached to another structure. Free-standing signs are of two (2) sub-types: low mounts which are less than seventy-two (72) inches in height and high mounts which are greater than seventy-two (72) inches in height. Sub-type distinctions shall not apply to signs all portions of which are at least fifteen (15) feet from the edge of pavement or curb of any public street. 
c.  Projecting sign: A sign which is attached to a building wall, and which extends more than twelve (12) inches from the face of such wall. 
d.  Suspended sign: A sign suspended from a building by means of brackets, hooks, or chains, etc., and not projecting more than twelve (12) inches in front of the portion of the building from which it is suspended. 
e.  Temporary sign: A sign primarily constructed of paper, cloth, unpainted or untreated wood, or a nondurable substance other than metal or plastic. 
f.  Portable sign: A sign placed upon a support structure, either external to the sign or integral with the sign, which is designed for portability. This definition includes, but is not limited to, signs mounted upon a wheeled chassis. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-02)  
Section 122. - Purpose of article. 
It is the intent of the following requirements to control the use of publicly visible displays, graphics, signs or billboards, in order to safeguard the public use and nature of the city streets and sidewalks, and to enhance the visual environment of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-01)  
Section 123. - Applicability. 
No sign shall hereafter be constructed, erected, or maintained within the corporate limits of the City of Prattville, contrary to the requirements hereinafter set out, and it shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect, or maintain any sign within the city limits of the City of Prattville except in conformity herewith. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-03)  
Section 124. - Penalty. 
Any violation of the provisions hereinafter set out shall be punishable in the manner and to the extent set forth in the Prattville Zoning Ordinance, as amended, in section 25. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-04)  
Section 125. - Severability. 
Should any provision of this article be decided by the courts to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole, or any part thereof other than the part held to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-05)  
Section 126. - Conflict with other ordinances. 
Whenever the provisions of this article conflict or overlap with another ordinance or another portion of the Prattville Zoning Ordinance, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-06)  
Section 127. - Appeals, variances and uses on appeal. 
Any person requesting a sign listed as a use on appeal for the applicable district, any person requesting a variance on the basis of unnecessary hardship, or any person aggrieved by any order of the administrator may appeal to the Prattville Board of Zoning Adjustment as provided by the Prattville Zoning Ordinance, as amended. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-07)  
Section 128. - Permit required. 
(a)  No sign shall hereafter be constructed, erected, replaced, changed in location or character, or altered in any dimension without a valid building permit issued by the Prattville Planning and Development Department, unless such sign category and type is specifically excluded or exempted by this article. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued for a sign until a sketch showing the proposed location of the sign, and any pavement, curb, public right-of-way or easement within twenty-five (25) feet of the sign, sign type, size, height, type of foundation, electrical scheme, illumination scheme, and any other information required by the administrator is received; the administrator shall review all such sketches and shall issue permits only upon the determination that such plan is in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-08)  
Section 129. - Excluded signs. 
The following signs are excluded from the definition of "sign" as it is applied in this article: 
a.  Any sign with a total area of one (1) square foot or less on any side; 
b.  Signs of a duly constituted governmental body or authority or public utility including, but not limited to, traffic or similar regulatory devices, legal devices, warnings at railroad crossings, governmental survey or boundary markers, and notices of water lines or buried cables; 
c.  Publicly owned memorial tablets or signs; 
d.  Signs required to be maintained by law or governmental order, rule, or regulation; 
e.  Signs of less than two (2) square feet in total area identifying the residents and/or address of any dwelling; 
f.  Street numbers if placed upon a building; and 
g.  Signs inside a building, but displayed through its windows. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-09)  
Section 130. - Exempt signs. 
The following signs are exempt from the permit procedure but must conform in all other respects to the requirements of this article, provided that they are not illuminated and do not have a total surface area on any one (1) side of greater than six (6) square feet: 
a.  Directional signs 
b.  Political signs 
c.  Real estate signs 
d.  Signs advertising yard sales 
e.  Signs of artisans, mechanics, or builders identifying their connection to active construction projects. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-10)  
Section 131. - Fees. 
Permit fees shall be determined in accordance with the procedures for determining building permit fees for other commercial construction. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-11)  
Section 132. - General sign regulations. 
(a)  No sign shall be constructed or placed in or over a public right-of-way that in any way interferes with normal or emergency use of that public right-of-way; any sign proposed to be placed in a public right-of-way shall be considered a use on appeal and require that the Board of Adjustment find that the proposed location is in the public interest after advertisement and a public hearing as provided by state law. The Board of Adjustment shall require the written opinions of the Chief of Police, the City Engineer, the Fire Chief, and the Administrator prior to making their [its] determination. The foregoing provision shall not apply to public event signs authorized by other procedures contained in this article. 
(b)  No sign shall be attached to utility poles, meter posts, or trees on any street right-of-way within the city. 
(c)  No person shall put up any sign or notice upon any building, wall, fence or other property not in their ownership without having first obtained the consent of the owner of such property. 
(d)  No sign shall be mounted on the roof of any building or painted thereon. 
(e)  No attached sign, projecting sign, suspended sign, or temporary sign shall project above roof line of the structure upon which it is mounted except that on structures possessing a parapet raised above the roof line, a sign may extend to the top of the parapet. 
(f)  One (1) freestanding sign shall be allowed for each public street directly bordering any parcel or lot. One (1) additional sign per street is allowed for each five hundred (500) feet of frontage, on that street, in continuous common ownership. Signs allowed by this section may be placed to property corners. 
(g)  No sign shall be erected or constructed at any location, whereby the position, size, shape, color, movement, or illumination would obstruct the view of traffic or cause the sign to be confused with any governmental traffic signal, safety barricade or emergency vehicle. 
(h)  Illuminated signs must conform in all respects to the electrical fire codes of the City of Prattville. In no case shall an electrical cord be permitted to lie upon the ground. Any other provision of this article notwithstanding, the Electrical Inspector, Fire Marshal, or Administrator may order the repair or removal of any sign which does not conform to these codes. 
(i)  Any light mounted on, mounted within, or directed toward any sign shall be so placed or screened that no direct illumination is cast upon any surrounding property or on or toward any public right-of-way. Signs shall not have any continuously flashing or blinking light unless such signs are setback at least fifty (50) feet from the edge of pavement or curb of any public street. 
(j)  On any lot or parcel where the principal building or structure is set back less than the required sign setback, the Administrator, after consultation with the Police Chief, Fire Chief, and City Engineer, may authorize a lesser setback if he/she determines that a public hazard will not be created. 
(k)  Construction signs shall be removed within ten (10) days after the completion of work. 
(l)  Real estate signs must be removed within ten (10) days of the closing of any sale. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-12)  
Section 133. - Special procedure for public event signs. 
Public event signs, as defined in this article, may be authorized by the Mayor of Prattville after consultation with the Fire Chief, the Police Chief, and the Administrator. Application for such signs shall be made in accordance with procedures established by the Mayor and upon forms and with such requirements as the Mayor may determine to be necessary. Signs authorized under this section shall be temporary signs as defined by this article and shall not be displayed for more than thirty (30) consecutive calendar days. 
(Ord. of 5-17-1988, § 10-13)  
Section 134. - District regulations. 
(a)  Determination of heights and areas of signs for all districts: 
(1)  Sign area shall be calculated as follows: 
a.  The area of an attached sign where the sign consists of letter[s], number[s], or symbols painted on or affixed to a wall shall be the entire area within a continuous perimeter enclosing the extreme limits of the message delineated by said letters, numerals, or symbols. 
b.  The area of an attached, suspended, or projecting sign, where the letters, numerals, or symbols are on a surface which is hung or affixed to a building shall be the total area of the hung or affixed area. 
c.  All other sign types shall be the sum total of the areas of all surfaces (excluding support structures) visible from the public right-of-way or other areas from which the sign is intended to be viewed. Only one (1) display face shall be measured in computing total sign area where the sign faces are arranged to be viewed one (1) at a time. 
(2)  Sign heights. Attached, suspended and projecting sign heights shall be measured from the uppermost surface of the portion of any walkway, entrance/exit or ground which lies directly beneath the sign. For the purpose of calculating low mount maximum sign heights and high mount minimum sign heights, determination of height shall be made from the point on the edge of any abutting public street or road to the point directly above, which lies on a line, perpendicular to the public street, intersecting the mid point of the highest part of the sign. The height of any other freestanding sign shall be measured from the base of the support structure to the highest point or part. Temporary or portable sign heights shall be calculated or measured in accordance with procedures for comparable permanent sign types. 
(3)  Except as specifically restricted in this article, all sign types permitted in each district may be used for all categories permitted in each district. 
(b)  Residential districts and trailer districts:
